Texto: MetLife has secured a breakthrough in its fight against US authorities over the insurer’s designation as a “systemically important” financial institution, a legal ruling with potentially far reaching implications for the country’s financial system.The ruling could encourage other financial institutions to mount legal challenges of their own and could lead to the dismantling of an important pillar of the Dodd-Frank legislative reforms that were enacted after the 2008 crisis, reports Alistair Gray in New York.Government lawyers had come under tough questioning from a district judge in Washington earlier this year as they sought to defend the process that led to MetLife being deemed a Sifi.The designation carries additional regulatory scrutiny and tougher capital requirements.Shares in MetLife, the largest US insurer by assets, jumped 5.6 per cent in the wake of the decision on Wednesday.

Titular: US life insurers shaken by rock-bottom rates
Subtitular: Industry titans hit almost as hard as banks amid macroeconomic concerns
Texto: Life insurers are supposed to be bedrocks of financial stability, dependable institutions whose long-term business models set them apart from scandal-hit banks.Yet shares in the leading US insurers, which help millions of Americans through retirement, have been anything but stable in recent weeks. Titans of the industry have been hit almost as hard as lenders in this year’s stock market rout.Shares in Lincoln National, the third largest listed US life insurer by assets, have dropped 23 per cent — more than any S&P 500 bank. The two biggest, MetLife and Prudential Financial, have lost more than 13 per cent even after a partial recovery this week.Many of the macroeconomic woes that have led investors to sell bank stocks have also made them nervous about life insurers.The biggest worry is rock-bottom interest rates, which push up the value of the insurers’ liabilities and make it a struggle for them to generate adequate returns on their vast investment portfolios.Stock market volatility, energy sector fragility and regulatory uncertainty have added to the pressure.For seasoned insurance analysts it is little wonder the sector has been battered. Life insurers’ valuations track closely 10-year bond yields, which have been at or near record lows for years.“You can usually tell how the industry is going to trade based on what the 10-year is doing,” says Steven Schwartz an analyst at Raymond James.This week Japan became the second country to sell such bonds at a negative yield, following Switzerland. Yet yields do not need to be sub zero to cause big problems for insurers. Ultra low is bad enough.Insurers traditionally invest the cash they get from policyholders largely in corporate and government bonds. Too much allocated to racier asset classes, such as equities, would threaten their ability to pay claims.However, the era of depressed bond yields has made the sector’s conservative approach to investments increasingly perilous.Life insurers are constrained in how much pain they can pass on to customers. They have sold savings and retirement policies that offer consumers minimum returns — and need to meet promises made years ago when interest rates were higher.Products with guarantees account for between 60 and 80 per cent of US life insurers’ balance sheets, Moody’s estimates. The average outstanding guarantee is between 2 and 4 per cent.The companies seek to match their liabilities by investing in long-term assets. But the match is often far from perfect.“There are some products where it’s almost impossible to find investments that go out as far as the cash flow on the policies,” says Scott Robinson at Moody’s. Liabilities associated with long-term care insurance stretch out for decades, for instance.Rating agencies are concerned insurers are being tempted to turn to riskier asset classes to deal with the problem. Fitch says it “remains concerned about the strategies that life insurers may use to reach for additional yield.”Downgrades of energy bonds caused by the oil price fall are another concern. As of the start of the year 13 of the largest US life insurers held $67.2bn of energy assets, according to Morgan Stanley. Energy accounts for about 7 per cent of the typical insurer’s investment portfolio.It is not only fixed-income markets that are causing a headache. Turbulence in equities is also bad news for the sector.Lower stock prices mean lower fees for insurers’ asset management arms.Stock market downturns also make variable annuities (VAs) — popular retirement-income products in the US — harder to manage.VAs are backed by equities, which can give consumers stock market-like returns. But they also offer lifetime guarantees, protecting policyholders against heavy losses.To meet the guarantees the insurers attempt to hedge their exposures. But they have had mixed success in doing so. “Does the hedging work? There’s always concern about that,” says Mr Schwartz of Raymond James.VAs are forecast to generate an average 14 per cent of earnings this year at seven US life insurers tracked by Morgan Stanley. Some companies have far greater exposure. They are set to account for almost half of Lincoln Financial’s 2016 profits — helping explain why its shares have been hit particularly hard.On top of unfavourable financial markets, the industry is also facing regulatory challenges.VAs, which tend to be sold through financial advisers, are expected to be hit by proposals from the US Labor Department to tighten standards for distributors.The rule would require brokers and advisers to act as “fiduciaries” — putting their consumers’ interests first.The change could put financial middlemen at greater risk of legal challenges for alleged mis-selling — and reduce incentives for them to sell complex products such as VAs in the first place.Dennis Glass, Lincoln’s chief executive, moved to reassure Wall Street on a recent call with analysts. Even the most “adverse scenario” would be “manageable”, he said. Only 30 per cent of the company’s annuity sales in the fourth quarter came from products it expected to be impacted by the Labor Department’s crackdown.Meanwhile, Prudential, MetLife and AIG are also facing higher capital requirements after officials deemed them “ systemically important” financial institutions.Supervisors have yet to quantify the consequences of designation, but that has not stopped MetLife from setting out plans to break itself up to soften the anticipated regulatory blow.Despite the pressures, few analysts are worried about the sector’s financial strength. The industry-wide “risk-based capital” ratio — which compares the amount of capital with the minimum required — had improved from 413 per cent in 2009 to 491 per cent at the end of last year, according to Morgan Stanley.The businesses are still throwing off plenty of cash, helping them return capital to shareholders through dividends and buybacks.Prudential Financial has paid out $9bn since the start of 2011. In December it raised its dividend by a fifth. MetLife increased its dividend 7 per cent last year. In total the insurer distributed $3.5bn to shareholders in 2015.The three largest life insurers by assets are trading at discounts of about 30 per cent of their respective book values. Many analysts argue this presents a big buying opportunity.“The industry is very well capitalised,” says Mr Schwartz, adding of the sell-off: “It’s way, way, way over done.”European life insurers have had just as tough a start to 2016 as their US counterparts. Share prices of the largest companies are down heavily, writes Oliver Ralph in London.Allianz, Aviva, Legal & General and Prudential are all down between 10 and 15 per cent in the year to date. The Southern Europeans have had it worse — Italy’s Generali and Unipol, and Spain’s Mapfre, are all down by more than a fifth.Like the US life insurers, the Europeans have had to cope with low interest rates and, since January, volatile capital markets. Low interest rates are especially painful because in some markets — notably Germany — the insurers have sold products that guarantee investment returns well above what is available in the market today.The Europeans have also had to deal with the added complication of the EU’s Solvency II rules, which were introduced at the start of January and force them to make tough decisions about the assets they hold.“Under Solvency II, the insurers need to optimise their assets for risk, return and capital consumption,” says Patrick Liedtke, a managing director in BlackRock’s insurance asset management team. “That’s not an easy equation to solve.”For some insurers, Solvency II has meant a move into government debt. “If your solvency capital level is not where you’d like it to be, then it is the asset class of choice,” says Mr Liedtke.But wherever possible, the insurers are looking for higher yields. “They are getting as much exposure to government debt as they need, then trying to use the risk budget to get more exposure to higher yields,” he adds. That is leading many of them into corporate bonds and infrastructure debt, where demand often exceeds supply.Solvency II has also forced the insurers to be more open about how fluctuating markets affect their capital. For example, when it reported its results last week, French insurer Axa said that its Solvency Capital Ratio (available capital as a percentage of the minimum required) was 205 per cent at the end of December, but that market movements had since pushed it down to about 190 per cent.

Titular: Puerto Rico creditors make counter offer on restructuring
Subtitular: Investors seek to avoid haircut while providing debt relief to the island
Texto: A group of Puerto Rico bondholders has made the first counter offer since the commonwealth proposed a significant restructuring last week with a plan that would secure full principal payment from the US territory.Investors holding senior debt issued by the Puerto Rico Sales Tax Financing Corporation, known by its Spanish acronym Cofina, have sought to avoid a haircut while providing debt relief to the island.The offer from creditors including Goldentree Asset Management, Metropolitan Life Insurance and Whitebox Advisors would postpone payments until 2018, giving policymakers on the island time to reinvigorate economic activity, improve tax collection and tackle Puerto Rico’s high poverty and unemployment rates.Under the plan, the commonwealth would suspend repayments to Cofina creditors until 2018 — a debt moratorium a working group launched by the commonwealth have also proposed — before steadily rising to at least $600m a year by 2021. Payments due in the commonwealth’s 2016 fiscal year by Cofina have already been set aside with its bond trustee.The investors estimate the proposal would provide relief of between $2.6bn and $3.7bn over the next decade.Conceived in 2006, Cofina was structured to attract investors to the island’s paper at a time when Puerto Rico faced significant strain tapping debt markets.The independent debt authority, which has amassed roughly $17.2bn of debt, was guaranteed a certain portion of revenues generated by a new sales and use tax, separating it from the island’s general fund.However, nearly a decade of economic downturn have depleted the island’s cash reserves. Policymakers now argue that funds set aside for Cofina should be used to service Puerto Rico’s $49.2bn debt pile, including general obligation bondholders who enjoy a constitutional guarantee.$49.2bnPuerto Rico’s debt pileUnder the so-called working group’s proposal, the island sought to cut the government issued debt by 46 per cent, including a nominal haircut of more than 50 per cent on outstanding Cofina paper.The net present value of the proposed cut is far larger, as the bonds would be repaid over a longer time horizon than when they were originally issued, investors say.Susheel Kirpalani, a partner with Quinn Emanuel, the law firm representing the senior creditors of Cofina, said the group’s proposal would provide the commonwealth the much needed liquidity it has asked for.“We will wait and be patient until the commonwealth has the ability to repay and can build back up to health,” Mr Kirpalani said. “But at least we’re not sacrificing our principal and our rights.”The senior Cofina plan would prioritise their repayment over subordinated debt holders, with expectations of a full par return for the senior liens between 2034 and 2047 in three economic scenarios laid out by the working group.*Charts above are based on projections to 2060 and do not indicate the full impact on subordinated debt beyond that date*Mr Kirpalani notes that if the plan received backing from a majority of the roughly $7bn in senior note holders, subordinated holders would be bound by the agreement.“It’s a way to at least solve the Cofina part of the puzzle,” he added. “I don’t think it is in anyone’s interest to litigate. This provides liquidity that the general fund needs.”The plan would also amend how the sales and use tax revenues are divided between the commonwealth and Cofina bondholders — splitting the taxes as they are generated. Under the current set-up, Cofinas receive the entirety until a certain threshold is reached.The proposal also conceived a mechanism for subordinated retail investors, who cannot wait for the senior bondholders to be paid in full, to receive remedies earlier.At a panel for Congressional staff members last week, advisers to the commonwealth said they believed Puerto Rico could manage as much as $1.7bn in debt service a year, but that they needed time to push through economic reform.Investors and policymakers agree that the island is likely to default on some of its most senior debt this July if it is unable to agree to a restructuring. Puerto Rico has already defaulted on bonds issued by two of its agencies.‘We’ve run out of tricks, we’ve run out of emergency measures,” said Melba Acosta Febo, president of the Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico.eric.platt@ft.comTwitter: @ericgplatt

Titular: MetLife gets sympathetic hearing over Sifi challenge
Subtitular: Judge says government assumed ‘worst of the worst of the worst’
Texto: US authorities that subjected MetLife to tougher oversight because they deemed it a potential threat to financial stability assumed the “worst of the worst of the worst”, the judge who will rule on the legality of their move has said.The largest US insurance company by assets on Wednesday squared off against government lawyers as it challenged its designation as a “systemically important” financial institution, or Sifi, in a federal court in Washington.If MetLife wins and the decision is upheld, it could lead to the dismantling of an important pillar of the Dodd-Frank legislative reforms that were enacted after the 2008 crisis.During the hearing, government lawyers came under tough questioning as they sought to defend the process that led to MetLife being deemed a Sifi. The designation carries additional regulatory scrutiny and tougher capital requirements.“That’s not a risk analysis,” said the district judge, Rosemary Collyer, at one point. “That’s assuming the worst of the worst of the worst of the worst.”Eric Beckenhauer, the Department of Justice lawyer who represented the government, defended MetLife’s designation as the “considered judgment” of the heads of “major financial agencies of the country”.Members of the Financial Stability Oversight Council — a body set up in response to the crisis — voted nine to one in favour of determining that MetLife poses a potential threat to financial stability. Its members include Janet Yellen, Fed chair, and Jack Lew, treasury secretary.The judge noted that the authorities only had to pass a low bar in identifying what could threaten the financial system. She also challenged several arguments made by MetLife. Yet she gave the government side a tougher time.In particular she was critical of the way the council reached its decision, questioning the independence of the civil servants who had gathered the facts. The judge grilled Mr Beckenhauer on "who decides what, and at what point"."I'm having trouble with the term 'adjudication'," she said. "There's nobody neutral in the process."Eugene Scalia, the partner at Gibson Dunn & Crutcher who represented MetLife, argued FSOC had engaged in “total speculation” about the risks posed by MetLife. He criticised the process as a “black box” and contended that MetLife was often kept in the dark about the basis for the council’s decisions.Mr Beckenhauer hit back. “The record clearly shows the opposite,” he said. MetLife had a “full and fair opportunity to be heard.”He said the authorities had engaged with the company for 17 months, held several meetings with its representatives and conducted a robust analysis.To succeed, MetLife needs to convince the judge that the authorities had acted in an “arbitrary and capricious” manner.Jaret Seiberg, analyst at Guggenheim, said he expected the government would prevail."While there may be some comments during the hearing, it is important to always recall that some judges will play devil’s advocate with their questions," he said.AIG and Prudential Financial, two other non-bank institutions that have also been labelled Sifis, are watching the case closely as they could be affected by the outcome.AIG is coming under pressure from activist investors to break up to avoid the Sifi tag. MetLife last month unveiled plans to sell off a big chunk of its business as it attempts to soften the regulatory blow.The legal ruling is not expected for several months and an unfavourable outcome is likely to be appealed.

Titular: Banking can learn from insurance on systemic risk
Subtitular: The dynamic between insurers, regulators and shareholders should be instructive
Texto: When Italy’s Generali managed to get itself off the global list of systemically important insurance companies in November, there were cheers in Trieste.Removal from the nine-strong list of insurers, deemed systemically important financial institutions (Sifis), meant a huge administrative problem evaporated. So did the prospect of tougher Sifi capital requirements from 2019. Generali’s secret had been to shrink and simplify its business. First it sold its US life reinsurance business to France’s Scor. Then it sold Swiss private bank BSI to Brazil’s now troubled BTG Pactual.The moves convinced regulators at the Financial Stability Board that Generali was no longer a global Sifi (replacing it with another European insurer, Aegon).They also gave US peers — and their shareholders — ideas.MetLife, the biggest US insurance company by assets, has been on a mission to shake off its Sifi label ever since it got it. A year ago, it took legal action against the US regulatory body, the Financial Stability Oversight Council, to challenge the designation. A couple of weeks ago, it announced plans to shrink, by spinning off a unit that generates 20 per cent of profits. This may have been a ruse to ditch a low-margin business but it may also prove a canny way to avoid the Sifi requirements, providing another route map for big rivals.AIG, and its agitator in chief, Carl Icahn, are watching closely. The US number four is barely half the size it was when it collapsed in 2008. But for Mr Icahn, and fellow rebel shareholder John Paulson, far more is needed. They have piled pressure on Peter Hancock, AIG’s chief executive, since launching a break-up campaign last autumn.Mr Hancock is this week set to outline a plan to ringfence troubled assets and other legacy business in an effort to see off the three-way split that Messrs Icahn and Paulson are championing.That idea was born of a desire to boost the group’s share price, which has come down 8 per cent since the rebel campaign began, though still up 8 per cent during the past year. But it could see AIG escape Sifi status, too. According to a recent Bernstein poll, 75 per cent of AIG shareholders would welcome that outcome.30The number of banks deemed systemically important by the FSBThe black-box exercise that the FSB and FSOC engage in when deciding on Sifi labelling is frustrating for insurance companies and puzzling for everyone else. Generali escaped the designation more than two years after it sold the US business that looked like a principal risk, and only after it had also sold a pretty banal private bank.Quite why Aegon has suddenly been included is similarly mysterious. The Dutch group only scrapes into the top 20 insurers in the world, ranked by market capitalisation, and is barely a tenth the size of the biggest, China Life, which is not designated a Sifi.Most illogical of all is the absence of any reinsurers on the Sifi list, particularly the likes of Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway, Munich Re or Swiss Re.All the same, the regulators are right in their aims. Basing their assessments on both size and complexity makes sense, and penalises the kind of balance sheet risk — and financial market complexity — intrinsic to, for example, annuity guarantees underpinned by elaborate derivatives contracts.It is also a useful check on the merger and acquisition fever that gripped insurers — like other hot sectors — last year. Get too big and the economics no longer add up.The dynamic between insurers, their regulators and their shareholders should be instructive for the banking industry, 30 of whose number are deemed systemically important by the FSB.Despite the turmoil, and all the talk of banks being under pressure, there has been little sign of the biggest balance sheets shrinking on either side of the Atlantic. With a few blips, JPMorgan has grown consistently since the financial crisis and now has a $2.4tn balance sheet. The same goes for BNP Paribas, with €2.1tn of assets. Over a similar period, HSBC’s assets of $2.5tn are almost unchanged.All three attract the highest capital surcharges of 2 or 2.5 per cent of risk-weighted assets. Share price performance has been poor. HSBC is down 24 per cent over the past year. BNP is down 10 per cent. JP is down 1 per cent. And yet, there has been almost no pressure from big activist investors on the behemoths of banking. That needs to change.

Titular: AIG forced to turn up the heat in battle to repel Icahn
Subtitular: Chief executive Peter Hancock likely to come out fighting with long-awaited strategic update
Texto: Carl Icahn’s fight with executives at American International Group over the activist investor’s push to split apart the most valuable US insurance company is becoming increasingly ugly.A slide deck distributed by financiers sympathetic to AIG claims that the septuagenarian’s previous efforts to make changes at regulated financial services companies have “often yielded disastrous results for shareholders”.For his part, in his latest open letter to the board, Mr Icahn accused AIG’s executives of “misleading” investors by putting financial information that he believes to be “materially inaccurate” in the public domain.The billionaire — who has received support from hedge fund manager John Paulson — also alleges that top managers, led by chief executive Peter Hancock, are resisting a break-up partly to protect their own bonuses.The activists, who claim to have backing from other shareholders, believe that Mr Hancock may yet abandon his opposition to their proposal to separate AIG’s life and general insurance arms.Mr Hancock is in no mood to do so, according to people familiar with his thinking. They say that he is likely to come out fighting when he presents a long-awaited strategic update on Tuesday.He is expected to detail his own scheme to narrow AIG’s focus, improve its efficiency and become more transparent to investors — a less radical course, but one that his backers say should produce superior returns.The company is in need of some. Shares in AIG trade at about 30 per cent less than their book value, a discount to rivals.Activists contend that the valuation gap can be closed if the insurer, which has a market capitalisation of $68bn, be split up. They say federal regulations that classify AIG — along with MetLife, GE and Prudential Financial — as a “systemically important” financial institution, or Sifi, make its conglomerate corporate structure untenable.Such arguments were given more weight this month when MetLife set out a plan to divest large chunks of its life assurance business, citing the Sifi regime. Shares in MetLife have since outperformed the US financial sector by 10 per cent.It echoed a historic decision last year by GE to hive off its banking business. For critics, AIG looks isolated in not taking such radical steps.However, the logic that prompted MetLife’s move does not necessarily apply to AIG.The business MetLife plans to shed is especially hard hit by the Sifi rules. It is a big writer of “variable annuities”, which guarantee minimum returns to policyholders. Companies that sell such products bear the risks of volatility in financial markets, so regulators insist they have more capital to back them than traditional underwriters.Joshua Shanker, at Deutsche Bank, says he is “not convinced that what is good for MetLife is an obvious prescription for AIG”.Washington has yet to quantify the consequences of Sifi designation. Still, critical AIG shareholders say that whatever rules are finalised, the direction of travel is clear.“They’re going to have to serve a life sentence [for the crisis],” says one of the company’s largest 30 investors. “The Fed wants them to break up. It’s very clear that now Washington would see that as a victory.”People close to AIG reject that assertion. AIG has played a big part in the post-crisis reordering of US finance.Since its $185bn taxpayer rescue, the insurer has transformed itself, shedding about $93bn worth of assets from aircraft leasing to consumer finance. The group, which has returned to profitability and repaid the bailout funds, is confident that the Sifi rules will be manageable.That said, this week Mr Hancock is expected to signal his willingness to walk away from underperforming or non-core businesses — via disposals, if the price is right. AIG is preparing a partial listing of its mortgage insurance arm, estimated to be worth about $6bn. A much smaller subsidiary, a broker dealer network called Advisor, is also on the block.Josh Stirling, an analyst at Bernstein, says that other disposal candidates could include a retail insurance business in Japan, which could fetch about $5bn, and Valic, the public sector retirement provider worth an estimated $10bn.Mr Icahn has made clear he will not be satisfied with what he calls “incremental changes”. Yet such steps could be enough to quell a rebellion from the wider investor base — especially since Mr Hancock argues that an outright split would entail big costs.AIG pays virtually no tax, a legacy of the huge losses it racked up during the financial crisis and its aftermath. The insurer is not alone in applying losses to reduce its tax liability. But AIG is thought to have among the biggest such “deferred tax assets” in the world. The company has valued it at $15bn, meaning it expects to pay hardly any tax for several years.Those in the AIG camp say the group would forgo about a third of this benefit were it to prise apart its life and general insurance operations. The reasons cited are rather arcane, given the complex tax and accounting rules, but the impact is important.“He’s basically correct from a strategic point of view,” says Brett Horn, analyst at Morningstar of Mr Icahn. “The issue is the tax.”Mr Icahn disputes AIG’s analysis of the tax implications of a break-up. Several independent analysts say the picture is unclear.AIG could help itself by clarifying how it arrives at its calculations, says Meyer Shields of KBW. “They must provide more information to substantiate their claims.”For the KBW analyst, the debate effectively come down to one question. “Is the upside to any spin-off enough to compensate for the lost tax benefit?”

Titular: Carl Icahn sees lessons for AIG in MetLife shake-up
Subtitular: Activist investor seizes on rival’s move to slim down in push for insurer to break up
Texto: Carl Icahn has stepped up pressure on American International Group as the activist investor pushes for the insurer to break up, seizing on rival MetLife’s move to offload a chunk of its business.The Wall Street billionaire on Tuesday said a radical plan unveiled by MetLife last week to slim down was another sign that AIG needed to become a “smaller, simpler company”.In his latest open letter to the board, Mr Icahn moved to pre-empt AIG executives’ attempts to rally shareholder support with a long-awaited strategic update they plan to set out next week.“I suspect, after two months of waiting, management will release [an update] that fails to present a drastic strategic shift and instead is limited to only incremental changes such as small-scale asset sales and incremental cost cutting,” he wrote. “If this occurs then the little credibility management now has will be lost.”Mr Icahn argues a split of AIG’s life and general insurance arms would allow it to avoid US authorities’ “systemically important financial institution”, or Sifi, label — which brings with it higher capital requirements.MetLife, which has also been deemed a Sifi, highlighted the new regulations when it disclosed plans to shed a chunk of its retail arm, saying they threaten to make the combined business uncompetitive.However, AIG’s senior managers have rejected the break-up logic, arguing a split would result in a higher tax bill, fail to free up capital and “distract” from cost-cutting initiatives.In response to Mr Icahn’s latest missive, the company said: “AIG continues to take steps to narrow its focus, improve its financial performance and return capital to shareholders. AIG maintains an active dialogue with shareholders, including Carl Icahn.The insurer reiterated it would update on its strategy “and its proactive plan to drive shareholder value” next week.Mr Icahn, who joined the ranks of AIG’s five largest shareholders with a 3.4 per cent stake, also cited a recent poll by the broker Bernstein that found limited support for chief executive Peter Hancock.“I believe management’s credibility with shareholders is all but gone,” claimed the investor, adding he hoped the board would “take matters into its own hands if management still resists drastic change.”

Titular: Aviva opens ‘digital garage’ in technology push
Subtitular: Insurer invests in technology to harness big data analytics to help boost productivity
Texto: Few investors would associate exposed brick walls, table footie and vintage posters in London’s trendy Hoxton Square with insurance.But this “digital garage” is one of two sites set up by Aviva to explore and develop all things digital. The other, opened last month, is located in a 1930s art deco former art gallery in Singapore.“We’re being encouraged to break every rule in the book, and not feel constrained by traditional ways of doing things in the industry,” says Andrew Brem, the former Asda and Carphone Warehouse executive who was brought in to run Aviva’s digital strategy in December 2014. He manages about 100 people at the digital garage, from website creators to data analysts to games developers.The FTSE 100 insurer is one of several in the sector investing in technology in an effort to harness big data analytics to help remain competitive and boost profitability. By analysing data, for example, the company has found that pension savers tend to be better drivers, so it offers car insurance discounts to its pension customers.Germany’s Allianz announced the formation of a unit called Digital Transformation in November. Italy’s Generali is also investing heavily. And in the US, insurers such as MetLife and MassMutual have committed millions to tech start-ups.Compared with other industries, however, insurers are playing catch up. Free of stringent regulation and legacy IT systems, fintech is booming, with start-ups attracting billions of dollars of investment as they tap into new technology providing online financial services from payments and lending to digital currencies and cross-border transfers.“We are a little bit late to the game,” says Kurt Karl, chief economist at Swiss Re. “I’d say we are two to three years behind other industries but the interest has cranked up enormously.”A lot of the millennial generation are asking why technology hasn’t shown up in insurance, and who will be the first to do itHe attributes much of the tardiness to the nature of the industry. “It is a conservative industry. We buy ‘bads’ rather than ‘goods’ and the nature of the business makes us cautious.”That, however, is starting to change. Investors poured $2.6bn into insurance tech start-ups in 2015, according to data from CB Insights, which tracks private tech investing.“It is about now that a lot of the millennial generation are beginning to ask about insurance,” says Eric Emmons, a managing director at MassMutual’s venture capital fund. “They are asking why technology hasn’t shown up in insurance, and who will be the first to do it.”The need to digitise and innovate is being fuelled by low interest rates, pricing pressure, regulatory change and the need to diversify.“The industry has come under an enormous amount of earnings pressure, driven by the low interest rate environment,” says Marty Lippert, head of global technology at MetLife. “The industry has to take a different view of how it operates. Efficiencies are important and we have been working hard to take costs out.”The industry is focusing on two areas. The first is the relatively dowdy world of back-office systems. “Over the past two or three years, big insurers have been looking at legacy systems, which have been creaking at the edges,” says Nigel Walsh, head of UK insurance at Capgemini. “You can’t deliver modern, agile services on systems that were built 30 years ago.”Only once the basic systems have been fixed, analysts argue, can insurers really start to innovate and use “big data” to take a comprehensive look at risks across the business. Automation is also a part of the process. “There is a big opportunity in taking paper-based processes out,” says Mr Lippert.Customers are getting more savvy. Expectations have gone up but insurers are not meeting those expectationsThe second focus is customers. “Customers are getting more savvy,” says Mr Walsh. “Expectations have gone up but insurers are not meeting those expectations.”For many insurers customer contact comes once a year — when the policy renewal is due. And few customers relish that moment. A survey by Boston Consulting Group and Morgan Stanley in 2014 found that customers interacted less with insurers than with any other industry. They also rated their online experiences with insurers below those with other industries. This explains why so much effort has gone into doing the basics better.At the digital garage, for example, Aviva is developing a system that allows customers to see all their Aviva products on one screen, and is also cutting the number of questions that customers have to answer before buying a product.But the ambition to get closer to customers goes much further. Insurers see the much-hyped “internet of things” as a huge opportunity. By measuring how people drive (through telematics) or their physical activity (through wearable devices) the industry hopes that it can persuade its customers to cut out risks and so push down the cost of claims. And if they cannot be encouraged to do so, at least the insurers will be able to price risks better.

Titular: Insurers commit $1bn to tech start-ups
Subtitular: Industry moves to catch up with other financial services operators reaping digital dividends
Texto: Some of the world’s biggest insurers have committed more than $1bn to investing in technology start-ups as the industry attempts to play catch-up with other parts of the financial services sector and boost profitability.European insurers such as Axa, Aviva and Allianz, along with MassMutual and American Family in the US and Ping An in Asia have all set up specialist venture capital funds dedicated to investing in start-ups that may be relevant for their core businesses.The latest deal will be announced this week, with Aviva and other investors putting £1m into Appyparking, an app that helps find empty parking spaces.Analysts said insurance has lagged behind other parts of financial services when it comes to digital investment, but say that interest has picked up sharply in recent months in a bid to stay competitive and harness big data analytics.“We’ve been investing a lot in digital and encouraging people to be innovative, but it is also important to capture innovation externally,” says François Robinet, chairman of Axa Strategic Ventures.The Axa fund initially started in France with €10m to invest but now has €230m to put to work globally.Last year was a record one for such deals, according to research firm CB Insights. By November, start-up investments by insurers were 43 per cent higher than the whole of 2014 and 725 per cent ahead of 2013.“The priority is financial return,” says Eric Emmons, managing director at MassMutual Ventures. “We’re running a for profit venture capital firm. Once companies are in the portfolio, we’ll do what we can to make our colleagues at MassMutual aware of them.”Other insurers, such as MetLife and Generali, have taken a different route and invest in conjunction with existing venture capital firms. However last year Generali went further and bought full control of MyDrive, a UK-based telematics business.Insurers have taken a wide definition of what might be relevant investments to make. According to CB Insights, between 2010 and 2015 just 13 per cent of investments were in insurance technology companies. As well as the parking app, Aviva Ventures has invested in Cocoon, a home security business while Axa has backed a start-up that forecasts the price of airline tickets.“We are looking at technology that will be relevant in three to five years,” says Ben Luckett, managing director of Aviva Ventures, “especially around the internet of things”.Data have been a big focus for investment. “Big data is a buzzword that is thrown around a lot,” says Mr Robinet. “As an insurer, all we create is data and a lot of energy has gone into using it better not just to drive customer centricity but also to underwrite better.”

Titular: MetLife: Looming smaller
Subtitular: Insurers are breaking themselves up to escape tighter regulation. Banks could do likewise
Texto:
Citigroup and JPMorgan executives might step outside their New York headquarters today, look south along Park Avenue at the MetLife Building, and shake their fists at it. The insurance group’s decision to split its business is a blueprint for any activist wishing to pursue the same course of action at a major bank.MetLife is fighting its designation as a “systemically important financial institution” or Sifi, which brings with it return-crushing capital requirements. But the rewards of restructuring were too great to ignore. The division which sells life insurance to individuals and accounts for a fifth of operating profits, will be split off, escaping the Federal Reserve’s capital regime altogether. The remaining MetLife will remain under tight regulatory supervision, but should benefit from a lower minimum capital level. Returns on equity at both companies should improve. Shares in MetLife, which are 40 per cent below their pre-crisis peak and down 18 per cent in 12 months, rose 7 per cent in after-hours trading.The most obvious external impact is on fellow insurer AIG, itself fighting demands to split from activist Carl Icahn. According to a Bernstein poll,
75 per cent of its shareholders said they wanted AIG to shrink and escape its Sifi designation.Mr Icahn has proven with Apple, and may again with AIG, that no company is too big or complex to be immune from activists. So the fact that the biggest universal banks are not facing the same level of pressure is strange. Admittedly, unlike the insurers, they cannot escape the regulatory regime altogether; big banks are automatically Sifis. But there is a gradation based on size and complexity, with equity minimums between 7 and 11 per cent of risk-weighted assets. Bank of America, JPMorgan and Citi could all expect higher returns from breaking up. They plead vaguely that the synergies of staying together are worth more. Activists could do everyone a favour by making them prove it.

Titular: MetLife unveils break-up plan
Subtitular: Life insurer says tougher rules could make it uncompetitive
Texto: MetLife has unveiled a plan to break itself up, warning that a move by US authorities to hit the life insurer with tougher regulations threatens to make a big slice of its business uncompetitive.The largest US insurer by assets on Tuesday laid out a proposal to float or sell a chunk of its retail arm in a deal expected to be worth about $10bn.The separation could put further pressure on rival AIG to make similarly radical changes as it comes under attack from Wall Street financiers Carl Icahn and John Paulson.They want AIG to take steps to remove its classification as a “systemically important” financial institution, or Sifi, which will subject it to higher capital requirements.Unlike AIG, MetLife is fighting its designation as a Sifi. MetLife disclosed its planned carveout just weeks before a court hearing in its legal battle with US authorities over its “systemically important” status.MetLife said it had not been approached by activists and had taken the decision to hive off the business itself.Investors appeared to welcome the plan. Shares in the S&P 500 insurer leapt 7 per cent in after-hours trading.Steven Kandarian, MetLife chairman and president, said in a statement that the business being shed would be put “at a significant competitive disadvantage” by the Sifi tag.“Even though we are appealing our Sifi designation in court and do not believe any part of MetLife is systemic, this risk of increased capital requirements contributed to our decision to pursue the separation of the business.”The new company is expected to be too small to merit classification as a Sifi, reducing its regulatory burden.Jay Gelb, analyst at Barclays, said in a note that while the remaining business would probably still be subject to the Sifi regime, it would not be hit so hard. The remainder of MetLife would be smaller and its composition would be different.As a result of the split, MetLife — whose history stretches back to 1863 — would effectively stop selling life cover to everyday Americans, except in very small amounts.Even though we are appealing our Sifi designation in court and do not believe any part of MetLife is systemic, this risk of increased capital requirements contributed to our decision to pursue the separation of the businessInstead it would be focused on administrating the life cover that it has already written, serving corporate clients, property-casualty insurance and operating overseas.MetLife’s plan is the latest step in the reordering of US finance under the influence of post-crisis regulation.It echoes a move by the industrial conglomerate General Electric, which last year announced it was beginning a series of steps to shrink its GE Capital division before applying for “de-designation”.A sale of the MetLife assets could interest Japanese groups, which have been on a global buying spree, or possibly private equity houses, but they could be too big to be acquired by another global insurer.Meanwhile, MetLife is making preparations for a stock market launch.The business to be carved out has about $240bn of total assets, about a quarter of MetLife’s total. It is among the US’s largest providers of annuities and life cover, and generates about a fifth of the group’s annual profits.The business is a writer of so-called variable annuities (VA), which provide income for the over-50s. Regulators have signalled that such “capital-intensive” products could be hit with especially onerous requirements under the Sifi regime. However, MetLife has already scaled back its VA business.Mr Kandarian said the break-up would have strategic benefits.“This separation would also bring significant benefits to MetLife as we continue to execute our strategy to focus on businesses that have lower capital requirements and greater cash-generation potential,” he said.

Titular: MetLife mulls overhaul amid regulatory squeeze
Texto: MetLife, the US insurer, is mulling plans to jettison a large swath of its retail operations as it looks to avoid higher capital requirements resulting from its designation as a systemically important financial institution.The New York-based company said on Tuesday that it’s “evaluating structural alternatives” for the business, including an initial public offering or a sale. The newly-formed company would represent about 20 per cent of MetLife’s overall operating earnings, and 50 per cent of operating earnings of MetLife’s retail segment.One of the reasons for the potential move is because the retail division is currently part of a SIFI business and therefore subject to significant capital requirements, according to Steven Kandarian, Metlife’s chief executive.The SIFI designation is a central part of a new US regulatory regime put in place after the financial crisis designed to reduce the systemic risk posed by institutions that are “too big to fail” and avoid future bailouts by taxpayers.Metlife is appealing the SIFI designation in court, arguing that unlike counterparts, such as the largest US banks, it shouldn’t be subject to the stringent, and costly, requirements.However, Mr Kandarian said breaking MetLife up would give the unit “greater focus, more flexibility in products and operations, and a reduced capital and compliance burden”.

Titular: AIG’s chief executive begins fightback against activist investors
Subtitular: Critics say insurer needs to deliver something extraordinary to satisfy rebellious shareholders
Texto: Peter Hancock’s fightback began in the middle of last month, with a gathering of investors at American International Group’s low-key headquarters overlooking New York’s East River.The chief executive, accused of a catalogue of failings by Carl Icahn, the veteran activist investor, spoke of years of under-investment in technology at the insurer, even before the grim years following the rescue by the US government at the height of the financial crisis. He complained of being dealt a bad hand, according to people familiar with discussions, noting that AIG had to dump 30 businesses in short order to pay back the government.One investor is left unimpressed, but sympathetic. “He’s under a lot of pressure, and he didn’t have a lot of good answers,” he says. “Let’s give him until January to see if he does. Even the greatest CEO in the world would have a hard time fixing [AIG], as is.”Other outsiders agree that Mr Hancock will have to come up with something extraordinary at a strategy update next month, if he wants to head off a rebellion among shareholders. So far, the measures have left many of them underwhelmed.The burly 57-year-old Briton has promised to dismiss almost a quarter of the top 1,400 members of senior management, while ditching old technology and pledging to buy back shares. But the three main business areas — life, property-casualty and mortgage insurance — remain.The most recent share buyback announcement came this month, on the same day that the US Federal Reserve signalled an end to the crisis era by putting up interest rates after a nine-year freeze. But critics argue that AIG has yet to pull off a similar exit from its own troubled past.The group’s return on equity over the past 12 months was 6.9 per cent, well short of the low teens ROEs of peers and AIG’s own target of 10 per cent.The core of the problem, says Josh Stirling, an analyst at Bernstein, is AIG’s status as a “globally significant financial institution”, which means it is subject to the most intense level of supervision by the Fed. AIG was the first non-bank to be designated as such in July 2013, after regulators judged that it could pose a serious threat to the stability of the financial system if it ran into trouble.According to Mr Stirling, this status has created a culture of “comfortable deference” to the Fed and an “overwhelming focus on de-risking,” as well as an extra billion dollars or so of annual compliance costs.He points to a lawsuit from MetLife, another big insurer, to rid itself of the designation, and efforts by General Electric to shake off the tag by selling about $200bn of financial assets. AIG should do likewise, he says, and “shrink itself to greatness” by selling itself — piece by piece — to competitors.“It’s a tremendous pain in the neck to be a Sifi, and that point can’t be argued with,” says one major shareholder. “If it was easy to be a Sifi, GE would still have its financial services division.”According to Mr Hancock, however, the Sifi designation is irrelevant. He has argued that the only practical constraint on AIG’s returns is the attitude of the credit rating agencies, which have always rewarded diverse businesses with conservative balance sheets.If Sifi peers such as MetLife and Prudential are achieving higher ROEs, it is because they choose to run their operations with more leverage, and are willing to take more risk, including through derivatives. Because of its near-death experience just a few years ago, say insiders, AIG would rather play it safe.Insiders also argue that Mr Icahn — who declined to be interviewed for this story — has bitten off more than he can chew with this rare venture into financial services. They say he is mistaken, if he thinks he can apply the same playbook he used on Coca-Cola, Motorola or Dell to a complex, multi-line firm which is subject to oversight by about 200 regulators around the world, besides the Fed.But, for the time being, it is the activists who appear to be working harder to win over the neutrals. On Tuesday Bernstein hosted a conference call that attracted 140 institutional investors. One of them, Paulson & Co, is wholly supportive of Mr Stirling’s proposal to shrink AIG via asset sales, according to people familiar with the situation.Within a few days of Mr Hancock’s November meeting with investors, Mr Icahn had issued a direct challenge to the CEO, saying that shareholders might back the election of a new board member who could replace him, over time.One big investor notes that Mr Icahn retains the option of proposing a whole new slate of directors — which could prompt the current crop of 13 to review their support for the 14th, the CEO. “I doubt it is unconditional love, like for a firstborn child,” the shareholder says.For now, says another shareholder, “there is tremendous scepticism within the financial services industry as to whether [Mr Hancock] is the right person to lead AIG”.

Titular: Lockdown life puts a strain on lawyers’ mental health
Subtitular: Homeworkers look to video apps and virtual tools to replace human interaction with colleagues and clients
Texto: Lawyers’ mental health is taking a hit as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, with studies finding partners and associates feeling stressed and isolated.Covid-19 has triggered global lockdowns and forced the legal industry to adapt to suddenly ubiquitous technologies such as videoconferencing platforms Zoom and Google Hangouts.Use of these tools has ensured the smooth running of much of the lawyers’ output but they have reported a toll on their mental health, which they blame on the lack of face-to-face interaction with colleagues and others.According to LawCare, a UK legal mental health charity, calls about the effects of coronavirus accounted for half of its helpline traffic since March 10. Lawyers reported feeling lonely and anxious about their health and job security.“The main thing people are calling about is pressure to go into work and not being allowed to work from home,” says Elizabeth Rimmer, LawCare chief executive. “We had one call very recently from someone with a family member with [Covid-19] symptoms who was not allowed to work from home.”Others are dealing with anxiety connected to homeworking, she says. “Particularly younger lawyers are feeling that they are on their own and haven’t got someone they can easily ask about things.”Firms are instigating virtual hang-outs including Friday night videocon drinks as a way of retaining a sense of team bonding, or offering courses such as meditation onlineA worldwide survey of 108 lawyers and law firm staff at all levels of seniority by RSG Consulting, the FT’s Innovative Lawyers research partner, also found isolation and lack of interaction constituted one of the main challenges of remote working, Women were twice as likely as men to report being affected by this.Most solicitors — and particularly more junior lawyers — are used to working closely within a team, often under high-pressure and close knit conditions that can be difficult to replicate in a virtual world.According to RSG, some 14 per cent of associates surveyed cited isolation and lack of personal interaction as the main challenge of working from home, compared to just 6 per cent of equity partners.“We are trying to keep morale up but it’s worse for the younger lawyers who are often alone in flats in London and feel more alone than the lawyers with families,” says one senior lawyer at a US firm based in the capital.Firms are instigating virtual hang-outs including Friday night videoconference drinks as a way of boosting morale and retaining a sense of team bonding. Other offerings include online courses in mindfulness and meditation.Some firms have devised similar systems to mirror human interaction via a screen. Linklaters’ corporate team, for example, has set up a “virtual coffee room” that remains open 24 hours a day.“The idea is that if people want to go and have a cup of coffee and a chat they can go in and see who’s around. I got five associates the other day and we had a coffee together on the videocon line,” says James Inglis, corporate partner at Linklaters.Meanwhile teams are having to grapple with new ways of communicating, via Zoom, Google Hangouts, Microsoft Teams or WhatsApp, which brings unique challenges.“We did have someone message our team WhatsApp group accidentally, inviting their friends round for dinner. Someone in our team responded asking if their friends could bring round some loo roll,” says one corporate partner.Some law firms, such as Mayer Brown, already had the infrastructure in place for employees to work from home, making the move to doing so full time during the pandemic more straightforward. Sally Davies, the senior partner in the London office of the international firm, says communication is critical, both internally and with clients.“We asked partners to set up regular calls with teams to listen and assess how people were coping,” she says.Often, the best technology is developed in times of crisisThe firm created an internal communications portal and a global messaging tool, and encouraged one-to-one virtual coffees particularly with new starters and trainees. It also set up response teams to act as central co-ordinators for client communications, though there is an expectation that every lawyer will reach out to their clients.Long-term positive changes may come from this: “We introduced [the online conferencing tool] Webex for all in a matter of a couple of weeks,” says Ms Davies. “Use the opportunity to develop new ways of working, a bit like [how] often the best technology is developed in times of crisis.”The fact that lawyers are used to working on deals and cases that cross jurisdictions and time zones means that most are used to handling matters remotely.“I have been practising law for 30 years in the City and in that time it has changed dramatically from requiring a physical presence for huge numbers of hours in the office, towards things like electronic data rooms where you don’t have to go anywhere to inspect documents,” says Simon Beddow, corporate partner at Bryan Cave Leighton Paisner.Transactional lawyers use “virtual deal rooms” in which document drafts are exchanged and questions answered in an entirely virtual world, sometimes without parties ever having to meet.However, not everything can be done in a virtual world. Site visits for due diligence purposes have been put on hold, which means that deals are paused, while company meetings that must take place in a certain physical location for tax reasons are kiboshed.Remote working has been quite good for team morale so far because we’ve been having a bit of a laugh with itCriminal lawyers are hampered too, in their inability to attend court. Jury trials were suspended in the UK last month in an attempt to safeguard those attending court, though some hearings can take place remotely.For others, however, the biggest change has been working-from-home attire and glimpses of each other’s home life.Charles Thomson, a litigator at global firm Baker McKenzie, says his team have been bringing pets to team Skype sessions and even showing up in their nightclothes to morning video calls.“We have been having daily videoconference catch-ups where some people are still in their pyjamas,” he says. “[Remote working] has been quite good for team morale so far because we’ve been having a bit of a laugh with it.”

Titular: MetLife to launch ‘pension Isa’
Subtitular: Tax-friendly savings account offers guaranteed income
Texto: Pensions providers are seizing on public interest in more flexible savings products with the launch of the first individual savings account (Isa) to offer an income guarantee.On Monday, MetLife will launch a new “pension-style” Isa which will enable savers to receive a guaranteed tax-free income from age 55 for life, no matter how long they live.“Savers are increasingly looking at Isas as part of their retirement planning but are concerned about the current options available,” said Dominic Grinstead, managing director of MetLife UK.“We believe Guaranteed Isas will be a major growth area which is why we have developed them as a tax-efficient savings solution.”The new product is an extension of the MetLife’s Guaranteed Drawdown product, which was launched for pension savers in September.Savers opting for MetLife’s Isa can invest from the age of 50 and take a guaranteed tax-free income from age 55 for life, no matter how long they live. Income rates depend on age, but would be 4 per cent at age 65. Customers can also opt for guarantees which protect their capital against market falls and have the certainty of a guaranteed amount at the end of their selected term.“It is good news that we’re seeing innovative new products being launched and products with guarantees could be of particular interest to those in retirement, for whom capital protection is likely to be at least as important as capital growth,” said Patrick Connolly, a chartered financial planner with Chase de Vere, the independent financial advisers.Automated service costs £199 — compared with £900 for a human adviserRead moreHowever, Mr Connolly said that while guarantees would be welcomed by some investors, they come at a cost.Income guarantee charges on the MetLife Isa start from 0.6 per cent and capital guarantee charges from 0.3 per cent.The total expense ratio (TER) for the asset allocation is 0.55 per cent and annual management charges range between 0.4 per cent and 0.7 per cent depending on the level of investment.Someone investing £50,000, for instance, would pay 1.85 per cent in the income guarantee and in the capital guarantee 1.55 per cent.“If people do require a guaranteed income as they get older, the most reliable and cost effective way to achieve this is likely to be through an annuity,” Mr Connolly.“If they want to remain invested then the extra charges of guaranteed products are likely to be a drag on performance over the long term.”

Titular: MetLife crashes the ‘lower for longer’ club
Subtitular: Top US insurer argues interest rates will not return to pre-crisis levels for at least a decade
Texto: MetLife joined the “lower for longer” club in dramatic fashion on Thursday, saying that a bleak economic outlook means that US interest rates are unlikely to return to pre-crisis levels for at least the next 10 years.Until now, the biggest US life insurer had assumed that it would take about three years for long-term interest rates to return to “normalised” levels. But on Thursday, when it presented third-quarter earnings, the insurer took analysts aback by extending that timetable radically — to 11 years, saying that low growth and subdued inflation would keep downward pressure on rates. Only in 2026, it said, will yields on 10-year government bonds reach its long-term assumption of 4.5 per cent.The move reflects a more pessimistic view of the global economy, explained John Hele, chief financial officer, on a call with analysts. Over the past 25 years, the 10-year Treasury — a benchmark for pricing trillions of dollars of car loans and mortgages — has yielded about 4.7 per cent.“I think given this year compared to even a few years ago where there was much more optimism about the recovery of the world economies, we see much slower growth for now and for the foreseeable future,” he said.The new forecast chimes with many issued by financial services companies during the latest earnings season, in which executives have signalled they expect rates — and thus returns — to remain near current levels for the foreseeable future.At Wells Fargo, for example, the world’s biggest bank by market capitalisation, chief financial officer John Shrewsberry gave colour on the bank’s “lower-for-longer” expectation for both short-term and long-term rates, saying that the bank was looking to squeeze out more income by adding more longer-term assets to its mix.Although Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen has kept alive the prospect of “lift-off” in rates next month forecasters still expect 10-year yields to reach just 2.3 per cent by year-end, down from estimates of 3.06 per cent at the start of this year, according to Bloomberg data.When challenged by one analyst to justify such a “dramatic change” in MetLife’s interest-rate outlook, Mr Hele said he had consulted widely with economists and academics before making the switch, which is part of an annual actuarial review.We see much slower growth for now and for the foreseeable futureFalling rates are a drag for life insurers, which have to reinvest maturing bonds at lower yields. Returns on the new money invested by MetLife during the quarter were about 100 to 150 basis points below the yield on the rest of its portfolio, said Steven Kandarian, chief executive. He described persistently low rates, combined with the gradual expiration of hedges, as “ongoing headwinds”.American International Group, MetLife’s big domestic rival, said this week that its net investment income dropped about a third from a year earlier. Combined with a loss from underwriting, that meant the group posted its worst quarter since the financial crisis, according to Josh Stirling, an analyst at Bernstein.AIG has come under attack by activist investors who accuse it of reacting too slowly to a world of lower returns.Analysts said most insurers have increased the length of time they expect rates to get to their long-term assumptions. But MetLife has put itself out on a limb.“An 11-year glide path is definitely at the long end of expectations,” said Steven Schwartz, an analyst at Raymond James.

Titular: Movers & shakers: August 10
Subtitular: Intermediate Capital Group hires Adam Goodman as managing director for US private debt team
Texto: • Intermediate Capital Group, the €20bn specialist credit manager, has hired Adam Goodman as a managing director for its US private debt investment team. Mr Goodman previously worked at MetLife, where he was head of mezzanine investments.• The Pensions Infrastructure Platform, the infrastructure business developed by the National Association of Pension Funds, has appointed Ed Wilson and Paula Burgess as investment director and chief operating officer respectively. Mr Wilson previously worked in Lloyds bank’s commercial banking division while Ms Burgess joins from CCLA, which specialises in managing assets for churches, charities, local authorities and other not-for-profit organisations• Kumaran Damodaran has moved to Stone Harbor, the $48.2bn New York-based investment manager, as a portfolio manager in the emerging markets debt team. Mr Damodaran previously worked at GLG Partners, the hedge fund.• Two hires for the multi-asset investments and portfolio solutions team at Schroders, the $487.4bn asset manager. Chris Hsia joins as a product manager after 16 years with Morgan Stanley, the US bank, while Mei Huang has moved from UK fund house HSBC Asset Management to take on the role of quantitative analyst.Schroders has also appointed Clara Yan as insurance-asset liability management director. Ms Yan joins from UBS, the Swiss bank.• Credit Suisse Asset Management has appointed Harald Réczek as head of distribution for the Swiss group’s Europe, Middle East and Africa business. Mr Réczek joins from German rival Deutsche Asset & Wealth Management.• Shayne Dunlap and Richard Marshall both moved from Mizuho Corporate bank in London to join the Absolute Return Government Bond fund team at Standard Life Investments, the £258.4bn Edinburgh-based asset manager. Chris Fellingham, chief investment officer of Ignis Asset Management, has decided to leave following the £390m takeover last year of Ignis by Standard Life.• Axa Real Estate Investment Managers is expanding in Asia with the opening of an office in Seoul, South Korea, that will be headed up by Cho Yun Seok as head of business development. Ms Seok joins the property investment arm of Axa IM from Simone Investment, a real estate investment manager in South Korea.• Neptune, the UK fund company, has appointed Valentine Bugeja as head of Switzerland. Ms Bugeja previously worked at M&G Investments as a sales manager.

Titular: Global insurers should be supervised at scale
Subtitular: Berkshire Hathaway ought not to evade too-big-to-fail rules
Texto: As Warren Buffett hosted the jolly 50th anniversary shareholder meeting of Berkshire Hathaway in Omaha, Nebraska, this weekend, tensions were rising over whether his company could imperil the world’s financial system. They are part of a tussle between US states, the federal government and global regulators over who should watch over the world’s largest insurers.The tensions have surfaced on both sides of the Atlantic, with Republicans in Washington protesting over the influence of the Financial Stability Board in Basel, and the Bank of England writing to the Federal Reserve to question Berkshire’s status. They are bound to grow as MetLife, the largest US life insurer, mounts a challenge to being designated as “too big to fail”.Some of this reflects a turf war. Insurance regulation is highly fragmented, with state insurance commissions traditionally supervising even large US insurers, rather than federal regulators such as the Federal Reserve. Both US insurers and their regulators want this to continue, and resent what they perceive as a power grab by Washington, encouraged from Basel.Much of it stems from the pivotal role of American International Group in the 2008 financial crisis. AIG, supervised by the defunct Office of Thrift Supervision and local insurance regulators, was belatedly found to have an insolvent derivatives trading unit, heavily intertwined with large banks and investment banks. Regulators and governments vowed that this should never happen again.It led to twin efforts to toughen supervision of non-bank financial institutions such as insurers. The first initiative is by the FSB to identify insurers whose collapse could imperil global financial stability. The second is by the US Financial Stability Oversight Council — a grand committee of regulators set up after the 2008 crisis — to pinpoint the most risky US insurers and to subject them to federal oversight.Each has come up with a list of “too big to fail insurers” on which AIG, Prudential Financial and MetLife appear. The FSB may add to its list reinsurers such as Munich Re, Swiss Re and Berkshire Hathaway, whose reinsurance operations include General Re. US regulators have not yet listed Berkshire, partly because it is such a large industrial enterprise that it may not qualify as a non-bank financial institution — it could be too big to be designated.State regulators are correct that insurers tend to be less fragile than banks because depositors cannot withdraw their money at will. In a crisis, insurers tend to have the luxury of time to run off their assets and liabilities. They are also right — as AIG showed — that good supervision means more than transforming insurers into financial fortresses with additional capital and liquidity rules.But the principle of consolidated supervision of large insurers is sound. MetLife operates in 50 countries through 359 subsidiaries and holds 25 per cent of its assets overseas, mostly in Asia. State regulators are effective in handling insurers with limited operations in a few states, but they can be overstretched by scale and scope. Group oversight makes as much sense for big entities in the US as it does for those in Asia and Europe.It is also vital for global reinsurers to be treated equally and to be covered by one framework. It would be absurd for one of the world’s largest reinsurers to receive a pass simply because its founder is revered as an investor and his company is so big that it can hold a sizeable reinsurer within it. Turf wars between Nebraska and Basel can hopefully be avoided, but if it comes to that, consistency should prevail.

Titular: Republicans attack new global insurance rules
Subtitular: Richard Shelby says international regime should not dictate how US companies are supervised
Texto: Global insurance rules face a revolt in the US as Republicans spearhead complaints that international regulators who they say lack accountability are imposing inappropriate standards on American companies.The financial crisis and the government rescue of US insurer AIG prompted a new regulatory regime for insurance, but the Republican takeover of Congress has brought to the surface deep unease over their development in the US.While the discontent in Washington is not universal, it signals trouble for the Financial Stability Board, a group of regulators and central bankers set up by the Group of 20 leading economies in 2009 to fortify the global financial system.At the head of the Republican attacks is Richard Shelby, chairman of the Senate banking committee, who used a hearing on Tuesday to showcase a range of concerns about the FSB’s influence.“An international regulatory regime should not dictate how US regulators supervise American or US-based companies,” he said in comments consistent with longstanding Republican scepticism towards a variety of international forums.He lamented that decisions made by the FSB — which is based in Basel, Switzerland — had been adopted “with what appears to be little independent evaluation” by the US’s umbrella group of regulators, the Financial Stability Oversight Council.The FSB decided that three US insurers — AIG, Prudential Financial and MetLife — are so critical to the financial system that they must be subject to tighter global regulation and potentially higher capital requirements. The FSOC has also designated the three as “ systemically important”.“The FSB is not a US regulator, and it is not accountable to Congress or the American people,” Mr Shelby said. “Therefore, the FSOC should not merely be a rubber stamp for the decisions made by an unaccountable international body like the FSB.”The FSB has no powers to enforce recommendations and instead relies on soft diplomacy of its members to ensure that its proposals are implemented by each country. The FSB declined to comment.An international regulatory regime should not dictate how US regulators supervise American or US-based companiesSix years after the crisis’s nadir, Mr Shelby’s comments come amid a wider debate over whether the FSB should be a treaty-based organisation such as the World Bank or IMF, which can sanction countries that do not implement measures. The US has also not signed up to certain IMF standards.Despite Republican concerns, signs of US sway at the FSB emerged this month with the revelation that the Bank of England had written to the US Treasury to ask why the reinsurance business of Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway was left off its list of “too big to fail” institutions.Mr Shelby controls what legislation emerges from the banking committee for a full vote in the Senate and is preparing a comprehensive financial reform bill.On Monday two Senators — Dean Heller, a Republican from Nevada, and Jon Tester, a Democrat from Montana — introduced a bill to “bring more accountability and transparency to the international insurance process”.We work with our international counterparts to build a global consensus that works for the United StatesThe FSB is due to promulgate capital requirements for insurers, which are being written by the International Association of Insurance Supervisors, and “resolution” standards for winding up insurers in the event of failure.Roy Woodall, an independent member of the FSOC and an insurance expert, told the committee that a “contorted international framework” was “why I think we should be cautious about ongoing initiatives”.He said: “There is still time to ensure that any international agreement consented to by the FSB is reached through a more open process that is in the best interests of the US.”Warren Buffett company left off provisional ‘too big to fail’ listContinue readingMr Shelby noted that Jack Lew, US Treasury secretary, had previously told the committee that FSB decisions did not bind the FSOC. Michael McRaith, a Treasury director, said on Tuesday that international standards are “not self-executing in the US”, because state and federal regulators study and test their impact before any implementation.“We work with our international counterparts to build a global consensus that works for the United States,” he said.David Green, the former head of international policy at the UK’s financial watchdog, said Mr Shelby’s comments were consistent with the “long-held congressional tradition of sovereignty”.“It is a quite carefully worded statement that does not necessarily disagree with the substance of FSB decisions, just that they have not been independently evaluated to satisfy that they meet US requirements,” Mr Green said.

Titular: Rothesay Life gears up for a potential £3bn IPO
Subtitular: Pensions insurer shrugs off the heightened competition since the industry overhaul
Texto: Construction workers are still putting the finishing touches on the Leadenhall Building, the City of London high-rise nicknamed the Cheesegrater.But Rothesay Life has already moved in, weeks before other tenants. The pensions insurer set up by Goldman Sachs has chosen the 47-floor landmark to be its new headquarters — a symbol of its ambitions as the business gears up for a potential £3bn listing.In an interview interrupted by occasional drilling, Addy Loudiadis, the insurer’s cerebral Anglo-Greek co-founder, sets out how she is readying the fast-growing business for the public markets.The mother-of-two established Rothesay eight years ago after cutting her teeth as a banker at Goldman, where she gained experience arranging complex derivatives deals.Since then Rothesay has become a big force in the “bulk annuity” industry. Companies have turned to it to lift headaches caused by their volatile pensions liabilities in return for a fee.After striking a series of pensions megadeals, Rothesay now insures the lives of almost 200,000 people. Last year alone it paid £700m worth of pensions.Yet a listing would come just as analysts are warning about increased competition.The life assurance sector is being shaken up by chancellor George Osborne’s overhaul of the pensions regime, which has caused sales of individual annuities to collapse.To make up the shortfall, mainstream insurers have piled in to the corporate market, which Rothesay specialises in along with rival Pension Insurance Corporation.James Mullins, partner at the pensions consultants Hymans Robertson, is expecting more insurers to enter the bulk annuity market this year, which “will dramatically increase competition and push down prices”.Ms Loudiadis, 50, says 2014 was “probably our worst competition year” for Rothesay. Yet she adds its returns were nevertheless “spectacular” and forecasts the market will continue to grow.The company is set to publish annual results on Monday showing a 33 per cent jump in annual pre-tax profits to £244m. “The UK is one large pension fund, with a couple of banks and aeroplanes,” she says. “There’s enough supply.”Rothesay’s chief points out that companies have been striking pensions insurance deals even when interest rates have been at rock bottom, making the transactions relatively more expensive for them. “If rates were up another per cent or two, there would be a floodgate.”Bulk annuity providers bear two big types of risks: that the assets that back the payouts generate weaker returns than expected, and that pensioners live longer than forecast.“This is not a very easy business — you really need to know what you’re doing. We are disciplined about our return. We don’t chase business,” says Ms Loudiadis.Although born in Nigeria to Greek parents, Ms Loudiadis attended Cheltenham Ladies College and has spent most of her life in Britain. After joining Goldman in 1994 she climbed up the ranks, becoming a partner and co-head of its European investment banking division.In 2001, the Oxford maths graduate helped Greece meet European deficit rules by arranging a derivatives deal years before the country’s debt crisis.The cure for cancer is anecdotally the worst thing that could happen to a business like thisMs Loudiadis, who has a penchant for yoga, is matter-of-fact about the potential dangers facing the pensions de-risking industry. “The cure for cancer is anecdotally the worst thing that could happen to a business like this.”Rothesay’s insured pensioners are forecast to live 17 years beyond retirement. An unexpected leap forward in longevity would hurt the company’s profits.Still, by reinsuring about 70 per cent of the life expectancy risks it has taken on, the group has shielded shareholders from the brunt of them. The group also has a conservative investment strategy.And Rothesay has thrived while its rivals have run into trouble.
