Lucida, set up by former Prudential chief executive Jonathan Bloomer, warned of “unattractive economics” of pensions de-risking before selling itself to Rothesay’s FTSE 100-listed competitor Legal & General.Part of the answer is to be bigger, Ms Loudiadis believes.Already Rothesay itself has snapped up two of its largest rivals: Paternoster, run by another ex-Pru executive Mark Wood, and the UK bulk annuity arm of MetLife, the US insurer.She indicates Rothesay may acquire more businesses shaken out of the industry by so-called Solvency II capital requirements that regulators are forcing on insurers next year.“There are opportunities out there which could double our size,” she says.Ms Loudiadis would like Rothesay — whose other shareholders include Singapore’s sovereign wealth fund and investment house Blackstone — to increase its assets under management from £13bn to at least £15bn before floating.“Scale does matter here. We would like another year [before listing], where we have the chance to prove categorically that we’re profitable, and we’re consistent,” she says.However, she adds: “Our job is to make sure that our shareholders have that [flotation] option — that if they do want liquidity, we are IPO-ready.”

Titular: GE Capital succumbs to changing regulatory climate
Subtitular: Executives accepted that the financial arm was worth more detached from its parent
Texto: The dismembering of GE Capital, the sprawling financial arm of General Electric, marks the next stage in a great reordering of US finance, heavily influenced by the US government.At first blush, it seems like strong deal markets drove Friday’s dramatic announcement that GE — America’s best-known conglomerate — would sell down GE Capital’s assets from $363bn to about $90bn, and return to its industrial roots.Executives were keen to emphasise that they had been confronted with increasing evidence that GE Capital was worth more detached from its parent.First, the spin-off of Synchrony Financial, a private-label credit card business and consumer finance company. GE floated it last year at more than $19bn and it is now trading with a market value of $25bn.Second, GE managed to sell an Australian consumer finance business to a KKR-led consortium for A$8.2bn last year, about twice book value.Third, GE received a flurry of confidential enquiries, mainly from private equity groups, about its remaining businesses, which include a middle-market lending platform. “People came and offered valuations that we thought, ‘That’s different’,” said one person familiar with the situation.But the regulatory climate was always a factor. GE Capital has been earmarked for special supervision ever since it was bailed out during the financial crisis with $130bn of government loan guarantees.To reduce the risk of future bailouts, Congress in 2010 gave regulators responsibility for selecting non-bank financial groups — “systemically important financial institutions (SIFIs)” — for tougher supervision.There had been debate over whether designation would be a “badge of honour” or a “scarlet letter” but the latter camp seems to have been correct. MetLife, the largest US insurer, is suing the government to try to escape its designation. Now GE Capital is planning to apply next year for “de-designation” after accomplishing more of the planned disposals.Even if all goes to plan, GE Capital will have to endure a brief period of strict oversight and the company has embarked on a massive recruitment drive to hire risk managers and financial modelling experts to help it prepare for annual stress tests by the Federal Reserve.People close to the matter said GE Capital had the most contentious relationship with regulators out of the four non-banks designated as SIFIs.In February, about the same time that he began drawing up a plan to dispose of most of his division, Keith Sherin, chief executive of GE Capital, wrote to the Fed to complain about the proposed oversight.In a 57-page letter, he said that “critical aspects” of the Fed’s plan “fail to satisfy . . . basic tests” to tailor supervision differently to that of banks. He argued the Fed was considering imposing capital requirements that were so stringent that they were “out of proportion” and would place GE Capital at “an unjustified competitive disadvantage”.The truth is that GE Capital was already at a competitive disadvantage, squeezed between banks which can borrow much more cheaply by paying depositors almost nothing for their funds, and more agile non-banks which have no limits on their leverage.Its performance has suffered. In 2008, looking — somewhat prematurely — to its post-crisis future, GE realised the world had changed but underestimated the magnitude. It estimated returns on equity would be down from 20 per cent to 15 to 20 per cent.In fact, the returns have been much worse. In 2014, return on equity was 8.6 per cent and would have been significantly worse without Synchrony. That is below GE’s cost of capital and a brake on the better performance of the industrial side of the company.Those returns are already hampered by regulatory capital requirements, which restrict the amount of debt the company uses, and could be worsened further if the Fed applies an even tougher regime that Mr Sherin railed against in his letter.Banks that buy some of GE Capital’s assets would also face the same problem of making good returns, although some might have the scale to do so.But buyers are expected to come predominantly from a pool of private equity groups that have invested heavily in growing their credit arms in recent years. Apollo, Ares, Fortress, Blackstone, GSO are already in the minds — some have already been on the phones — of GE and its advisers at Centerview and JPMorgan.The rise of those firms poses more questions about whether the focus of regulators on banks and a tiny handful of large non-banks, such as GE Capital, is distorting competition and whether it is making the overall system any safer.“The process was supposed to reduce risk in the system. This has to be the biggest question: are we reducing risk in the system or are we simply reducing risk in individual institutions?” says Mark Calabria, a former Senate banking committee aide now at the Cato Institute.Aaron Klein, a former Treasury official who is now a director at the Bipartisan Policy Center, asks: “Is financial risk like the law of thermodynamics? It can never be destroyed, it just moves around.”Additional reporting by James Fontanella in New YorkGE retreats from UK financial marketGeneral Electric is pulling out of the UK financial market, where it operates under the GE Money brand, in a move that will put billions of pounds of mortgage assets up for sale, writes Emma Dunkley.The US group revealed plans on Friday to shrink its global finance arm in order to return to its manufacturing roots. That move includes the retreat from the UK market and could lead to the sale of about £10bn of British mortgage assets.A number of specialist lenders and “challenger” banks in the UK are in talks with GE about potentially acquiring some of the assets, said people familiar with the situation.The group recently sold £250m of second mortgages to a specialist lender, but still has £10bn of primary mortgages on its balance sheet, the people said.“GE would’ve loved to have sold the UK mortgage business some time earlier, but there was no one around to buy, or the prices were unacceptable. But now, the price of the assets has gone up,” according to one source.Ray Boulger, of broker John Charcol, said: “Private equity firms have an interest in getting into higher margin parts of the mortgage business.”He said that GE Money was known for subprime lending before the financial crisis. The lender subsequently offered mortgages to customers that “represent good credit risk but do not have a perfect credit score”.“GE Money falls into this capital category, so it’s likely private equity funds will look at buying the existing mortgage book and using it as a launch pad to get into the UK market,” he added.1890Four companies representing inventor Thomas Edison’s interests merge to form the Edison General Electric Company1932GE Credit Corporation begins to offer credit to customers to buy General Electric appliances1981Under chief executive Jack Welch, GE Capital begins a dramatic ascent. Between 1986 and 1993 profits double to $1.5bn and assets to $155bn. GE Capital becomes the world’s largest car leasing company, the world’s largest ship container leasing company and the biggest private mortgage insurer2004GE Capital buys Dillard’s credit card unit for $1.25bn2008As the credit markets seize up, GE announces its first fall in quarterly profits for five years. In September, chief executive Jeff Immelt calls Henry Paulson, the then Treasury secretary, to say GE “was finding it very difficult to sell its commercial paper for any term longer than overnight”2011GE buys MetLife Bank, an online retail banking arm2013Mr Immelt sets a target that GE Capital should provide no more than 30 per cent of group earnings2014GE Capital has $7bn of net income, assets of $499bn and more than 35,000 employees. It operates in 40 countries. In the US, GE takes Synchrony Financial, its store credit card arm, public in a $2.88bn initial public offering2015Mr Immelt announces plans to sell the bulk of GE Capital over the next two years and return the company to its manufacturing roots

Titular: Chief who pulled AIG back from the brink
Subtitular: Robert Benmosche, who led insurer’s restructuring, dies aged 70
Texto: Robert “Bob” Benmosche, who pulled the world’s largest insurance company back from the brink in the wake of the financial crisis, has died, aged 70.The former chief of MetLife was plucked from retirement in 2009 to lead the restructuring of AIG, the New York-based insurer rescued by the US government with about $180bn of taxpayers’ money.By the time he stood down in September last year, AIG had paid the state back in full and had restored its stock market value to almost $70bn. In November, becoming more ill with cancer, he watched with pride at Soldier Field in Chicago, as 60,000 rugby fans — many with AIG’s logo on their chests — watched the All Blacks beat the USA Eagles.Standing six feet four inches, Benmosche was a bearlike figure with soulful eyes and a slow-breaking smile. He died on Friday morning in New York, with his family by his side.“My mom taught me in life, don’t take yourself too seriously. And I don’t,” he said in a commencement address to the class of 2013 at Alfred University of New York state, his alma mater. “What she said was, in life, people will kiss your buns on the way up, and they’ll step on your throat on the way down. Don’t forget who you are.”Born in Brooklyn in May 1944, Robert Herman Benmosche moved when he was five to upstate Monticello, New York, with his parents, Lillian and Daniel, who ran a restaurant and rented out roadside cabins. The sudden death of his father five years later — without any life insurance — left his mother and three siblings $250,000 in debt and with a half-completed motel. To make ends meet, the eldest son put in shifts around the motel and later, as a teenager, drove trucks for Coca-Cola.After graduating from Alfred with a maths degree, Benmosche joined the US Army, serving as a lieutenant in South Korea until 1968. Starting out in finance at Chase Manhattan Bank in 1976, he later joined the brokerage, Paine Webber, overseeing the acquisition of Kidder Peabody. But it was at MetLife, where he arrived in 1995, that he became more broadly known as a formidable and sometimes fearsome operator.“He had an unshakeable true north, in terms of doing what was right,” says Brady Dougan, chief executive of Credit Suisse, where Benmosche sat on the board for 10 years to 2013.He took MetLife public in 2000 and retired six years later to spend more time at Villa Splendid, his home outside Dubrovnik. In 2009 he celebrated the first wine from his vineyard, an hour up the Croatian coast on the Pelješac peninsula.But then came the call from Jim Millstein, a former Lazard banker then at the Treasury department, and in charge of monitoring AIG. Then-Treasury secretary Tim Geithner had set the bar low, saying that AIG should be successful enough to allow the government to exit. Benmosche had other ideas, telling a congressional committee that he would make the state whole.My mom said, in life, people will kiss your buns on the way up, and they’ll step on your throat on the way down. Don’t forget who you are“At the time, sceptics thought he was crazy,” says Peter Hancock, AIG’s current chief executive. “He had utter conviction — and that conviction was contagious.”His spell at the top, which involved sales of many assets and deep restructurings of others, was not without friction. He clashed with Harvey Golub, AIG chairman, who left in July 2010. And while other AIG chiefs — there were three in 13 months before him — were prepared to work for small sums, Benmosche held out for $10.5m, saying that it was up to the chief executive to set the tone from the top.If AIG were to truly recover, he argued, staff needed to hold their heads high. That included the swaps-trading division at the heart of AIG’s troubles, where retention payments one year came to $165m, prompting one Democratic congressman to claim that the country was “at war” with the insurer.In a video interview with Bloomberg’s Betty Liu last summer, mostly filmed around his vineyard, Benmosche was unrepentant about his stance on pay and the trouble it stirred, noting that sales of its stake in AIG had netted the government profits of almost $23bn.“You have to take risks in life. You’re going to have to take a decision,” he said, jabbing a finger, dressed in khaki shorts and a navy polo shirt. “And if you take a risk and you win, you shouldn’t be blamed for winning because the people who lose didn’t do so well.”His wife Denise, daughter Nehama, son Ari, and longtime companion Lisa were at his bedside when he died. He is also survived by another daughter, Beth; three siblings, Judith, Jayne and Michael; and six grandchildren.

Titular: Week in Review, January 17
Subtitular: Car party in Detroit; MetLife, oil projects, and drug deals also in the news
Texto:
A round up of some of the week’s most significant corporate events and news stories.Carmakers unveil electric and luxury-vehicle drivesTwo sharply contrasting parts of the automotive industry drew the biggest attention at the annual Detroit Auto Show, writes Robert Wright in Detroit.On Monday, during the very first press conference, General Motors revealed a concept for the Chevrolet Bolt, pictured — an electric vehicle intended to cost $30,000, after federal tax rebates, and have a 200-mile battery range.The vehicle appears squarely aimed at the plans by Elon Musk’s Tesla Motors for a mass-market Model 3 electric car whose specifications would be very similar to the Bolt. Such vehicles currently tend to have ranges shorter than 200 miles. Mr Musk insisted on Tuesday, during a rare visit to Detroit, that he welcomed such efforts by mainstream carmakers to make electric cars.He also predicted that his group would be selling “a few million” vehicles — on a par with BMW — by 2025, despite a slowdown of sales in China.News, commentary and analysis from this year’s event — the largest and most important annual showcase for US carmakers

Further readingAlso on Tuesday, Johan de Nysschen, chief executive of GM’s Cadillac luxury brand, pledged to spend $12bn over the rest of this decade on vehicle development to improve the marque’s competitiveness. Cadillac hopes to take on Mercedes, BMW and other luxury-vehicle manufacturers with wider, more attractive ranges.Cadillac’s announcement was one of many at the show by carmakers keen to capitalise on the US recovery to sell higher-margin performance and luxury vehicles.Ford also unveiled a concept for a high-performance supercar, while Toyota’s Lexus luxury brand announced plans to return to racing in the US and Europe, rather than just Japan.●Related video: Bolt from the blueMetLife insists it lacks clout to threaten systemMetLife is usually proud to be big and important. But this week was different for the US’s largest insurer by assets, as it filed a lawsuit against regulators in efforts to downplay its significance, writes Barney Jopson in Washington.The insurer has been classed as an institution that could threaten financial stability if it fell into distress — a designation that would subject it to tougher oversight — and MetLife is desperate to escape the tag.The latest step was to file a challenge against its designation as a “systemically important financial institution” in a Washington DC court this week, having lost a previous appeal last year.Imposing tougher regulations on not just banks but also other financial groups was a central part of the US’s response to the financial crisis, as written into the Dodd-Frank financial reform law.But MetLife’s move added to a sense that Dodd-Frank is coming under renewed attack from the financial sector, where some people regard it as poorly designed and unduly onerous.Also this week, Barack Obama signed into law a bill that contained a provision to give agricultural businesses and others that hedge risks with derivatives an exemption from Dodd-Frank cash cushions imposed on banks.The following day the House of Representatives passed a bill to delay part of the Volcker rule, a provision that limits bank risk taking.MetLife said it supported strong rules but argued it was not as integral as regulators have concluded, despite its widely held insurance products and heavy involvement in capital markets.●Related Lex note: MetLife — fight the SystemCrude’s fall halts projects worth billions of dollarsBillions of dollars of spending on oil and petrochemical projects was scrapped or called into question this week, as industry operators outlined cost-cutting measures to cope with the collapse in the price of crude, writes Michael Kavanagh in London.Royal Dutch Shell confirmed on Wednesday it had abandoned plans for one of the world’s biggest petrochemical plants, a $6.5bn project with Qatar Petroleum, blaming “the current economic climate prevailing in the energy industry”.For the past few months Jamie Dimon’s voice was hoarse and softer than usual, a side-effect of his treatment for throat cancer. The 58-year-old JPMorgan Chase boss, weakened, would take naps in his Park Avenue office. He lost 35lbs. For those who saw him during this period, the change was a bit unsettlingContinue readingA range of other operators also signalled that they would abandon or defer exploration and development projects unless there was an improvement in oil prices. Brent ended the week down 60 per cent since last summer at below $50.Statoil of Norway abandoned three exploration licences off the west of Greenland as part of a general slowdown in its Arctic drilling efforts aimed at trimming capital spending.London-listed Premier Oil also said it would delay a decision on whether to proceed with the $2bn Sea Lion project off the Falkland Islands , as well as its Bream project in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea, until oil prices recovered.Schlumberger, the world’s largest oil-services company, said on Thursday that it planned to shed 9,000 jobs as a result of the cutbacks in spending by energy groups.The threat of a collapse in confidence in the North Sea also prompted the UK government to commission an urgent review into the state of the country’s oil industry amid plans for job losses by BP and others.Meanwhile Tullow Oil, one of Africa’s leading explorers, called on governments across the continent to reduce taxes to prevent a collapse in investment. The plea came as Tullow booked a record $2.7bn in write-offs and impairments across its portfolio of assets.● Related in depth: Oil — The Big Drop
● Related Gillian Tett column: Finance can cope with cheap oil
● Related video: Has the oil price found a floor?Drugmakers dose up on $10bn of January dealsPharmaceuticals companies have begun 2015 in the same way as they spent much of last year — on the hunt for deals, writes Andrew Ward in London.Almost $10bn of acquisitions and partnerships have been announced in the past week as the industry continues its scramble for growth assets.Shire was the biggest buyer with a $5.2bn takeover of NPS Pharmaceuticals of the US aimed at bolstering its position in rare-disease medicines — one of the hottest areas of drug development.For UK-listed, Dublin-based Shire it marked the resumption of its expansion strategy after the collapse of a merger with AbbVie last year and provided an outlet for the $1.6bn break fee received from the US group.The NPS deal was a gamble because it came less than a month before US regulators were set to decide whether to approve its most promising experimental product — for hypoparathyroidism, a life-threatening hormone disorder affecting about 100,000 people in the US and Europe.Shire said it was confident of approval but the timing showed how larger pharmaceuticals companies are willing to take big risks on unproven assets from the biotech sector in an attempt to replenish drug development pipelines.Roche also had a busy week with a trio of deals worth up to $2.3bn, including the acquisition of a controlling stake in Foundation Medicine, a US genomic analysis company. The Swiss group also struck a licensing deal with Canadian and Japanese partners for a medicine that can make antibiotics more effective.● Related Big Read: Healthcare: Counting the cost of cancer
● Related Smart Money column: Are healthcare stocks good for your wealth?And finally …the lighter side of the news● Honesty is the best policy, but Woody Allen might be going a bit too far. While Amazon was lionising the cinematic stalwart as it revealed plans for him to write and direct a television series, he was blunt about a lack of inspiration, saying: “I have no ideas and I’m not sure where to begin.” Maybe he could create a show about a once-hilarious film-maker who falls into rehashing the same story with mature actors romancing young starlets.● Facebook, once the nemesis of employers, is looking to put the work back into social networking. The imaginatively named Facebook at Work is being developed to help share ideas and improve internal communication. But how long before those internal forums become an officially sanctioned way of wasting time, with rising stars competing for brownie points by liking the chief executive’s ice-bucket challenge video?● In the world of taxi-hailing apps there is turbocharged Uber, expanding at breakneck speed, and there are the rest. Hailo, for example, has been left at the side of the road waiting for a tow truck. This week the London-based app announced the appointment of its third chief executive in three months. Investors in the former start-up darling must be putting their faith in a tortoise and hare style reversal of fortunes.● The union between Samsung and Google’s Android operating system is losing its sheen. The South Korean group, whose smartphones have helped to propel the little robot around the world, is looking to wrestle back revenue by launching its own Tizen software on devices in India. Given the dominance of Google and Apple, the phone peddler may find it difficult to sever the wires binding it to the US tech leviathan.Back to the top of the page

Titular: MetLife to mount legal challenge to systemic risk label
Subtitular: Insurance group taking on FSOC to escape tougher regulation and oversight by Fed
Texto: MetLife is challenging a central part of the US’s response to the financial crisis by suing the government for classing it as an institution that could threaten financial stability if it fell into distress.The US’s largest insurer by assets, MetLife, on Tuesday filed a lawsuit against its designation by US regulators as a systemically important financial institution, which came last December after the company lost a previous appeal.The designation — based on MetLife’s widely-held insurance products and its involvement in capital markets — would subject the insurer to tougher oversight by the Federal Reserve.The insurer’s move is another attack from the financial services sector on the post-crisis Dodd-Frank legislative reforms from 2010, which placed a priority on tightening the oversight of businesses that could jeopardise financial stability.The reforms are also under fire from Republicans who have this year taken control of Congress.While MetLife regularly champions its “leading market position” in the US, its opposition to the designation is based on an argument that, while big and important, it is not as integral to the financial system as regulators have concluded.Steven Kandarian, MetLife’s chief executive, told the Financial Times: “We’re not contesting the law. We’re simply contesting the application of the law as it applies to MetLife.”He said MetLife had hoped to avoid litigation by giving regulators evidence that his group was not systemically important, and stressed that it was now taking advantage of a provision for judicial review in the Dodd-Frank law.The insurance industry as a whole had lobbied hard to escape the net, arguing that it was much safer than banking and was being punished for the past sins of AIG, which came close to collapse because of risky derivatives contracts it wrote.MetLife’s legal challenge will be the first test of the powers of a panel of regulatory chiefs called the Financial Stability Oversight Council, which was created out of Dodd-Frank and includes Treasury secretary Jack Lew, Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen and Securities and Exchange Commission head Mary Jo White.We’re not contesting the law. We’re simply contesting the application of the law as it applies to MetLifeWhen it designated MetLife as systemically important, FSOC said: “[M]aterial financial distress at MetLife could lead to an impairment of financial intermediation or of financial market functioning that would be sufficiently severe to inflict significant damage on the broader economy.”It added that its conclusion did not signal that MetLife was experiencing, or was likely to experience, financial troubles.AIG, GE Capital and Prudential Financial have already been deemed systemic risks by the FSOC, and are now overseen by the Fed. Of those companies, only Prudential appealed the council’s decision but declined to pursue a legal challenge.A Treasury spokesperson said it had been notified of MetLife’s complaint: “The council’s decision to designate a nonbank financial company is reached only after a thorough analysis and extensive engagement with the company, both of which occurred in this case. We are confident in the council’s work.”MetLife has been the most aggressive opponent of the systemically important label, arguing it would put the company on an uneven playing field with its competitors.Mr Kandarian — a former regulator himself — said he was a supporter of strong rules and was not concerned that the challenge would harm MetLife’s relations with its supervisors.The lawsuit would take up time and money, he noted, but added: “That is a small cost compared to not getting this right and putting us on an unlevel playing field where a couple of large life insurers are regulated differently than the rest of the industry, putting us potentially at a real competitive disadvantage.”The FSOC has been criticised by Democrats and Republicans for lacking transparency, and some lawmakers have called on the body to put a hold on it issuing Sifi designations while its operating procedures are reviewed.However, the council’s defenders argue that it plays a crucial role in bringing regulators together to monitor risk in the financial system in the aftermath of the 2008 crisis.MetLife has hired prominent legal counsel, including Eugene Scalia, who successfully challenged the SEC’s proxy access rule and is a son of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia.——————————————-Letter in response to this report:Good luck, MetLife, you deserve to win on merit / From Alex J Pollock

Titular: MetLife: Sifi move
Subtitular: With $1tn of assets, the insurer cannot deny its systemic importance
Texto: Insurers are a touchy bunch. MetLife, America’s largest insurer by assets, is so outraged at being labelled a “systemically important financial institution” (Sifi) that it may take the US government to court. Big banks are used to the designation, while insurers are relatively new to it. But is it really so strange to argue that an insurer with nearly $1tn of financial assets could be systemically important?The Federal Reserve and US Treasury say that a run on a large insurer – for example a mass cash out of life policies – would disrupt the entire financial system. Insurers acting like banks is also a concern. AIG failed during the financial crisis because it insured bad mortgage-backed securities. The multibillion dollar taxpayer rescue that followed still resonates in the American psyche.MetLife disagrees. Insurers’ standard argument is simple: we are not banks and AIG was an outlier. MetLife also argues that, unlike banks, it invests in long-term assets to match its long-term liabilities. It says a mass surrender of its policies is not possible as 60 per cent of its contracts cannot be shut over night. Many annuities and life policies can only be disbursed through regular payments, not all in one go. The remaining 40 per cent can be cashed out but only at hefty penalties. MetLife points out that during the crisis it did fairly well. Surrender rates were below 10 per cent (the industry average was low single-digits). Benjamin Lawsky, New York’s banking regulator, has come to MetLife’s defence. He says the insurer is properly supervised (by him, as it happens) and if it were to fail the resolution would be orderly.Many of these arguments are fair and insurers should not be regulated like banks. But that does not absolve them from close scrutiny. Regulators should regulate for the next crisis, not the last one – that MetLife did well last time is irrelevant. The failure of any institution with $1tn in assets could do serious damage to the financial system. Met Life fully deserves its Sifi status.Email the Lex team at lex@ft.com

Titular: Regulators propose systemic risk label for MetLife
Texto: US regulators on Thursday recommended that life insurer MetLife be designated a systemic risk to the financial system, setting up a possible legal showdown between the company and the Financial Stability Oversight Council.Out of all the companies that the FSOC had been seriously considering for systemic risk designation, MetLife has been the most aggressive in fighting the possibility, including considering a lawsuit.The company will probably take its time before deciding whether to pursue a legal challenge against the FSOC, which is made up of the heads of the US financial regulatory agencies. The appeals process could last up to five months.AIG, GE Capital and Prudential Financial have already been deemed systemic risks by the FSOC, and they are now overseen by the Federal Reserve. Of those companies, only Prudential appealed against the council’s decision but declined to pursue a legal challenge.The designation, which carries tougher oversight and capital requirements, comes amid growing criticism of the FSOC by some lawmakers and business groups, which have called for it to put a hold on systemic risk designations.They point to the council’s recent decision to focus on potential risky activities in the asset management industry as a whole, rather than on specific company designations, as evidence of unfair treatment of the insurance sector. MetLife has long argued that the FSOC should assess the insurance industry in terms of general activities instead of looking at specific companies.In July, the FSOC announced that it would focus on activities in the asset management industry, rather than on company designations.“This disparate treatment has led to uncertainty in the insurance industry and raised concerns that the council’s approach to insurance company designation is to ‘designate first, ask questions later’,” Congressman Scott Garrett and six other lawmakers said in a letter to Treasury secretary Jack Lew. Mr Lew is head of the FSOC.MetLife chief executive Steve Kandarian said the company strongly disagreed with the FSOC’s decision and it was considering its options.Imposing bank-centric capital rules on life insurance companies will make it more difficult for Americans to buy products that help protect their financial futures“Imposing bank-centric capital rules on life insurance companies will make it more difficult for Americans to buy products that help protect their financial futures,” Mr Kandarian said. “At a time when government social safety nets are under increasing pressure and corporate pensions are disappearing, the goal of public policy should be to preserve and encourage competitively priced financial protection for consumers.”FSOC defenders say the council plays a crucial role in bringing regulators together to monitor risk in the financial system. Companies reviewed by the FSOC also have a chance to provide their views.For instance, BlackRock, Fidelity Investments and other large asset managers lobbied heavily against any systemic risk designations, saying regulators should look at industry practices as opposed to focusing on the largest companies in the sector.Critics say that the tougher rules that come with designation as a systemically important financial institution (Sifi), including higher capital requirements, are designed with banks in mind, and may be inappropriate for other financial sectors.The Fed has argued that laws force the agency to impose bank capital requirements on companies designated as systemic risks. The Senate has approved a bipartisan bill that would give the Fed the flexibility to tailor capital requirements to the insurance industry.

Titular: The reinvention of pensions
Subtitular: Budget reforms could result in many new products
Texto: The U-shaped annuity. Deferred annuities that do not pay out for decades after they are bought and pensions that remain invested, but feel more like an annuity.Welcome to the retirement market of the future, where the array of products to deliver pension income is set to widen greatly in choice and complexity.Until now, most of the 400,000 people retiring in the UK each year have opted to turn their pension savings into a secure income for life in the form of an annuity. Far smaller numbers kept their funds invested in some form of income drawdown.But this is set to change from April, when pensioners will have new freedom to access these savings as a cash lump sum.“The old world, where the money was roughly divided into annuities for small pots, and income drawdown for bigger pots, that’s all swept away now,” says Billy Burrows of Annuity Line, an annuity broker. “People will have far more choice.”The government expects its reforms, announced in the Budget, will stimulate product innovation as pensioners are given freedom on how to spend their savings. But middle Britain – those savers with pension pots ranging between £30,000 and £250,000 – are expected to be most keenly targeted by providers with products that blend key features of an annuity and drawdown.“Until now, we have seen annuities that sit wholly at one end of the spectrum in terms of the guarantees and at the other end of the spectrum you have drawdown,” explains Tom McPhail, head of pensions research with Hargreaves Lansdown.“Product developers are now looking at this space and asking ‘where can we stop on the line between drawdown and an annuity’?”——————————————-Drawdown for the massesAnticipating a slump in core annuity business, pension providers are now switching their attention to developing products that will make drawdown more accessible and appealing to the mass market.In the past, according to data from the Association of British Insurers, fewer than one in 10 pensioners has opted to keep their funds invested in drawdown, with only 21,000 drawdown products sold in 2013 compared with more than 353,000 annuities, with only 7 per cent of these investment-linked.But keeping funds invested beyond retirement is expected to be recast as a mainstream option. Already, providers such as Standard Life and MetLife have lowered the minimum fund threshold for savers to enter drawdown.“Ultimately, it is our view that we will see a fundamental shift with fewer people buying an annuity at the traditional point of retirement,” explains Alastair Black, head of customer income solutions with Standard Life, one of the UK’s leading pension providers.“The key reason is that retirement can be a long period of 20 to 30 years. We see there being a shift towards some kind of ‘flexible income in retirement’ product, and in essence this is income drawdown.“Instead of simply choosing between an annuity and drawdown, people will ask ‘where am I invested and how much income do I take?’”——————————————-Capital and income guaranteesProducts which protect income, or capital, are expected to become more heavily promoted in the new pensions environment – particularly for pensioners who are not experienced or hands-on investors and who worry about outliving their capital.Two types of guarantees could become more widely marketed, including guarantees or insurance against future market falls and on income.News and comment on the UK pensions scene“The current annuity market will change massively, but the good things about annuities, including guaranteed income for life and no risk of running out of money, should be retained – which is where unit-linked guarantees can play a major role,” says Dominic Grinstead, managing director of MetLife UK. The company expects sales of the products to near treble to £4bn in the UK by the end of 2015.“Clearly, unit-linked guarantees are not suitable for all, but they enable advisers and clients to guarantee income and capital now and retain flexibility and freedom in the future as their circumstances change.”Axa, another pension provider, has just launched its first unit-linked guarantee product aimed at the newly liberalised UK market.“The product is designed to be very flexible to allow the client to take a higher level of income in the early years, and when they are not so active it will give a guaranteed income for life,” says Simon Smallcombe, managing director at Axa Life Invest.“The minimum capital we accept is £25,000, but we think that drawdown providers will go to a lower threshold as more people could benefit from drawdown protection.”——————————————-The U-shaped annuityIn the new era of freedom and choice, annuities are also set to receive a makeover to increase their appeal. Currently, income from a lifetime annuity may rise annually with inflation, or remain level, but cannot fall. However, annuities of the future may do so.“We’d like the ability to do all shapes of annuities, where income can go up as well as down to match retirement income needs,” explains Andrew Tully, pensions technical director at MGM Advantage, a pension provider.“People talk about their income needs changing throughout retirement. Those needs might be high when they first retire but drop down in their late 70s when they aren’t as active. But income needs will pick up again when they have care costs.“We would like the ability to make the payments go down and up, like a U-shape, in a predetermined way.”——————————————-Deferred annuitiesAs well as more flexibility over their income, pensioners could opt to buy an annuity which does not start paying until they are much older.Experts say deferred annuities, which are a bought with a single premium typically at retirement, but only begin to pay at a predetermined date, make more sense for many than simply buying a lifetime annuity at 65.“I think they are a really good idea,” says Philip Smith, director with PwC’s pensions team.“Regardless of the government’s reform I think they would have fitted very well with people who wanted to go into drawdown but who wanted a little more certainty. There’s a strong case for staying invested until you reach 75 or so, before you consider annuitising.”——————————————-‘Traditional’ annuityEven with product innovation to increase their appeal, there are concerns that annuities will become poorer value in the short term as retirees exercise their newfound freedoms.This is because of the “mortality cross subsidy”, whereby those unfortunate enough to die early effectively subsidise those who live longer than the average. If there are fewer unhealthy people buying annuities, the income rates offered to those who are healthy will fall.Get an idea of how much you should consider contributing and how much you could receive when you retire with our pension calculator“On balance, I think annuities will become poorer value unless firms are prepared to accept lower profit margins,” says Alan Higham, retirement director with Fidelity Worldwide Investment.“That won’t happen until the Financial Conduct Authority steps in to make it harder for them to sell annuities to their captive clients, and addresses the regulatory capital issues.”“In the longer term, I think annuities will become more competitive as the market settles down.”——————————————-Lifetime Pension AccountsWith the requirement to buy a product with pension savings abolished, it’s likely that savers will be encouraged to think of retirement as a journey, rather than an “event”, with accounts they can hold on to for life.“In the new regime, there will actually be no need to move from your pension provider at all if you want to take an income for retirement,” says Ros Altmann, an independent pensions expert.“Pension companies could develop ‘lifetime pension accounts’ which will cater for customers’ needs from beginning to end.“For the initial years, the fund would roll up all income and aim for strong capital growth. However, once the customer reaches later life, they can just contact the pension provider to ask them to start paying out their income.”——————————————-Bricks and mortarThe government’s reforms will mean that pension funds can be used next year to buy property, to deliver a regular income in retirement. But while bricks and mortar may feel a more intuitive investment for many than the stock market, advisers warn that property also attracts fees and charges and could be considered a high risk strategy.In the UK, the system has made it so you never had to think too hard about where your pension income was coming from. However, the world is changing and people will have to engage with their pension planning“Most buy-to-lets yield somewhere around 5 or 6 per cent per year, although there is potential for capital appreciation,” says Lauren Peters, pensions adviser with Tideway Wealth Management. “It’s a personal choice, which should be considered with caution, particularly if you anticipate investing a significant proportion of your pension savings and you have no other assets from which to draw a retirement income.”Whether it be bricks and mortar, a capital guarantee or a combination of products, experts say that it will be more important than ever for savers to engage with their retirement choices.“In the UK, the system has made it so you never had to think too hard about where your pension income was coming from,” says Ms Altmann – savers either received a final-salary pension from their employer, or they rolled accumulated savings into an annuity.“However, the world is changing and people will have to engage with their pension planning.”——————————————-What are the rules now and how are they changing?Currently retirement savings must be used to deliver a secure income, in the form of an annuity, or be kept invested in “capped” drawdown, where limits are imposed on how much cash can be taken each year. Only those with additional secure pension income of £12,000 a year, recently reduced from £20,000, have full freedom to access their savings in one hit. Savers with total pension wealth of £30,000 or less can take these funds as cash under trivial commutation rules.From April 6 2015, these restrictions will be lifted, giving all savers the option to take cash as a lump sum taxable at their marginal rate, with a quarter tax free.——————————————-Beware of ‘marketing wheezes’The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is being urged to be on guard for products rushed on to the retirement market as savers abandon annuities and look for alternatives.“I think we can expect some good innovation but we should also expect some bad practice,” says Debbie Harrison, member of the Financial Services Consumer Panel and a visiting professor of the Pensions Institute at Cass Business School.“The panel would like the FCA to be closely evaluating and watching every new product on the market. There is a danger that people could buy inappropriate and expensive products which are being rushed on to the market.”Financial advisers are already cautioning against a new breed of capital and income guarantees pitched at savers who want stock market exposure but with protection against exhausting their funds.“The cost of the guarantee is usually far greater than the benefits it provides,” says Patrick Connolly, certified financial planner with Chase de Vere, the independent financial adviser.“Depending on the needs of the client, we’d prefer to buy an annuity or go into conventional drawdown rather than plump for a halfway house where some form of compromise usually has to be made between the guarantees and the potential for a rising income.”Justin Modray, founder of Candid Financial Advice, says adding the total cost of the pension wrapper, investment fund, protection and advice might top 3 per cent a year, “which is prohibitive”.Nest’s pension price may not be right, but it’s a start, writes Jonathan Eley“For example, buying protection on a MetLife low risk fund over 10 years costs 1.2 per cent, fund charges add another 0.54 per cent and the pension wrapper costs a pretty hefty 0.7 per cent a year,” says Mr Modray. “You can only buy via financial advisers who might charge a further 0.5 per cent to 1 per cent year, so your total costs will probably be between 2.94 per cent and 3.44 per cent.”“Axa offers the option to protect investment income, albeit at a hefty price – the cost to protect a joint life income is between 1.4 per cent to 1.7 per cent a year with pension, fund and advice costs on top.”Mr Modray says savers could put together a “sensibly diversified portfolio” for about 0.7 per cent or less a year and with pension wrapper charges on top, end up paying around 1 per cent or less a year.“Your pension will not be protected, but the chances of making a loss over 10 years are relatively slim. In my view, these products will remain more of a marketing wheeze than truly useful until costs fall to a sensible level.”

Titular: AIG advances on core business strength
Texto: American International Group advanced as broker Goldman Sachs lifted its view on the insurance group to ‘buy’, citing the company’s ability to invest in its core businesses that continue to generate strong cash flows.The investment bank estimates AIG’s property casualty division and its life and retirement division will pay dividends of between $5bn and $6bn a year to the parent company between 2014 and 2016, up from roughly $3.5bn in 2012 and 2013.Shares of the company rose 1.94 per cent to $53.51 by the close. MetLife increased 1.37 per cent to $50.22, while Prudential inched 0.97 per cent higher to $81.09.Europe was the only sour note in the latest quarter for Tiffany & Co as the high-end jeweller reported a jump in earnings and lifted its profit forecast for the year.Sales growth in China, Japan, Australia and the US catapulted the New York-based retailer’s revenues up 13 per cent to $1bn in the quarter to April 30 from $895m in the same quarter the year before.Same-store sales – a key metric for retailers – climbed 11 per cent when excluding the effect of currencies, comfortably ahead of Wall Street’s forecast for 4.8 per cent.“If sales strength were to continue at the same pace in the US, Europe, and Asia-Pac, and we assume a slowdown in Japan given the pull-forward this quarter associated with sales tax change April 1, earnings per share could be in the $4.70 range,” Wells Fargo analyst Paul Lejuez said.The jeweller forecast earnings per share as high as $4.25. Shares in the company jumped as much as 10 per cent to $97.40, a record high, before closing up 9.1 per cent at $96.30.Shares of beleaguered department store chain Sears dipped 3.7 per cent to $36.56 after Sears Canada, the chain in which it holds a 51 per cent stake, reported a wider than expected loss in the quarter amid depressed winter sales.Sears Canada said it lost C$75.2m, or 74 Canadian cents a share, for the quarter, compared to a C$31.2m loss a year earlier. Sales declined 11 per cent to C$772m.Sears Canada shares fell 0.65 per cent to C$15.21.Sears, which has said it is exploring a sale of the unit, has itself struggled to right sales. Same-store sales at Sears dropped 7.8 per cent in the three months to February 1.US hotel operator La Quinta rose after the company eclipsed Wall Street’s expectations in its first quarter as a publicly traded company, following a disappointing initial public offering this April that saw the company sell shares below its initial targets.Revenues in the three months to March 31 rose 7 per cent from a year earlier to $227.7m, ahead of analyst forecasts for $225.2m, while its net loss narrowed 24 per cent from a year earlier to $7.3m.La Quinta also said it expected full-year adjusted earnings between $362m and $368m compared with estimates for $363.3m.The company, which operates 839 hotels with 84,000 rooms in North America, said it would work to reduce its outstanding debt in the current quarter, which totalled $2.1bn. Its shares rose 2.87 per cent to $17.19.Peers Hilton Worldwide and InterContinental Hotels Group rose 2 per cent to $21.85, and 1.66 per cent to $37.44, respectively.Shares of Booz Allen Hamilton fell 10 per cent to $21.86 after the management and technology consulting company reported a 9 per cent drop in quarterly sales, largely related to uncertainties surrounding the federal budget.Equities rose after the release of minutes from the Fed. The benchmark S&P 500 was up 0.81 per cent to 1,888.03 while the Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 0.97 per cent to 16,533.06. The technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite climbed 0.85 per cent to 4,131.54.eric.platt@ft.comTwitter: @EricGPlatt

Titular: Idea management software boosts collaboration
Subtitular: Idea management software is smart way to deal with staff suggestions, and boosts collaboration, says Jane Bird
Texto: Employees often have ideas for improvements at work – after all, who knows the business better? But few are put forward, let alone reviewed, refined and acted upon.Ending this huge waste of knowledge and creativity is the aim of idea management software. This helps organisations capture and evaluate ideas to identify the best, by letting people make suggestions, comment on each other’s proposals, collaborate and vote for winners.Simon Hill, chief executive of Wazoku, a UK-based idea management software supplier, explains: “It provides the information sharing that people are familiar with from Facebook, LinkedIn and Twitter but with more governance and control.”The software can handle huge volumes of suggestions. This year, Aviva expects to generate 800 entrants – double the number last time – for its Customer Cup challenge, in which employees compete to supply ideas to improve the customer experience. The insurance company is using Wazoku for the first time to run the tournament.Previous Customer Cups have been very labour-intensive, says Jan Gooding, Aviva’s group brand director. “Every employee had to be emailed a request to participate. To spread the word, we relied on old fashioned methods such as posters.”With Wazoku, Aviva can invite its 33,000 staff worldwide, in their native languages, to log on, stimulate their imaginations by looking at examples of previous winners, and submit ideas.Previously, people did not know what ideas their colleagues had submitted. “This time they will be able to inspire each other and join forces with people who have similar ideas, rather than each team working in the dark,” Ms Gooding says. She hopes the collaborative approach will create momentum and keep teams motivated.Lorenz Wyss, head of idea management at Swiss Post, says idea management software is particularly effective when used to address specific topics and problems. “It can also be used as a brainstorming tool, and as an instrument to rate ideas with the audience acting like a review committee.”However, he notes, organisations implementing idea management need to reassure people that their ideas will not be stolen, but rewarded and recognised. At Swiss Post, people are paid up to 20 per cent of the cost saving or additional revenue in the first year.MetLife, the US-based insurance company with operations in 46 countries, has found international collaboration to be one of the big benefits of the Mindjet idea management software it is using.Many companies say they are global, says John Geyer, MetLife’s vice-president of innovation. “But most of their staff rarely collaborate across national boundaries, even though they are often trying to solve the same problems.”MetLife is asking its employees in Russia, Japan, Iberia, the US and the Gulf to suggest ways to remove unnecessary procedures and processes. Managers were “blown away” by the results, says Mr Geyer.“The 460 people in the Gulf who were invited to participate, generated 440 ideas. Each idea had additional collaborators, many people submitted multiple ideas, and many who submitted none contributed to the ideas of others.”Ideas are usually collected for about a month, but some were so powerful and simple that they were adopted two weeks into the campaign, Mr Geyer says.Good idea management software helps decision making because it makes it easy for the “crowd” or experts to evaluate which ideas are best, says Michael Stilger, senior vice-president for global solutions, Qmarkets, another idea management software company.To help with the analysis, Qmarkets includes a simulated stock market tool that lets employees use virtual currency to buy, sell and make investments in each other’s ideas. For the best ideas, the value of a share goes up, like in a real stock market, says Mr Stilger. “It is a reliable forecasting technique.”Idea management software can identify innovative people who otherwise might never have been spotted. “It’s amazing how people who wouldn’t normally contribute to the innovation process because they are quiet and shy, will do so electronically,” Mr Stilger says.The prerequisite is that it has to be simple, says Mr Geyer at MetLife. “Facebook, Twitter and LinkedIn have become ubiquitous largely because they are easy to use. If you want 70,000 people to collaborate, it can’t be intimidating.”Giving employees the chance to take part in the development of the company is good for morale, says Mr Geyer. “People who’ve been with us 25 years say this is first time they’ve really felt valued, engaged with the direction of the company, and that management has considered their ideas.”Employees like the fact that everyone’s ideas are on view for people to see and vote on, so they can see how they are rated. In the past, they submitted their ideas into a “black box”, says Mr Stilger. “Now the ideas are like a living organism that people can see evolve.”Idea management software can also be used to gather suggestions from customers, but you do not want it to become a complaint box, warns Mr Stilger. “Lots of companies hesitate, because they think it could do more harm than good.”Despite the fact that Swiss Post pays staff for successful suggestions, idea management quickly pays for itself, Mr Wyss says. “The more ideas we get the more we get out of it,” he says. “If we spend one franc we get two francs back.”That sounds like a compelling proposition. And maybe the simplicity of the software will encourage companies to take up the challenge and listen to their staff.

Titular: Chilean pensions lure US investors
Subtitular: MetLife and Principal blaze a trail to the country’s pioneering private market
Texto: US asset managers are increasingly buying into a Chilean resource that could turn out to be richer than even its copper mines: its population’s golden years.Only six private sector investment houses are approved to manage assets in the country’s mandatory Administradora de Fondos de Pensiones, or AFP, scheme and two of them were bought by US groups last year – market leader Provida by MetLife and Cuprum, the fourth biggest, by Principal Financial Group.Chile’s upward mobility, combined with a transparent political and regulatory system and its pioneering embrace of defined contribution pension saving have created one of the world’s most promising retirement markets, says Oscar Schmidt, executive vice-president and head of MetLife in Latin America.“This balance in Chile between growth from an emerging middle class and relatively low risk – that is the sweet spot,” Mr Schmidt says.Created in the early 1980s, Chile’s pension system is built on individual savings accounts funded by mandatory 10 per cent salary or wage contributions. The assets are invested by one of six AFPs, which offer up to five government-approved portfolios invested according to differing risk levels.The mandatory savings are supplemented with tax-advantaged voluntary schemes known as Ahorro Previsional Voluntario, or APV accounts, in which assets are invested in private sector mutual funds or insurance products by the AFPs.As of February, the AFPs oversaw $160.4bn in assets, up 11.5 per cent over the past year, according to government data. Assets in the voluntary schemes rose 11.2 per cent in the year to September, to $7.2bn.Fuelling the rising trend is Chile’s robust economic growth, which its central bank projects will climb as much as 4.8 per cent this year. Pension fund assets in the country, meanwhile, are projected to rise at a compound annual growth rate of 11.7 per cent through to 2017, compared with 7.4 per cent in the US, according to data from Cerulli Associates, the research company.“This is a country that is going to be growing at a higher rate than the developed markets, and because of that growth we will have more new consumers demanding new products,” says Roberto Walker, president of Principal’s Latin American operations. “New growth will take place within the mandatory programme and will be even faster in the case of the voluntary programme.”Indeed, the voluntary scheme has attracted recent US interest as well. In the past month, Nuveen Investments and Federated Investors have announced distribution deals making their funds available.“Any time we see an emerging market that is developing with a stable and growing pension marketplace, we think our product line fits it,” says Gordon Ceresino, executive director for international distribution at Federated and president of Federated International Management.Chile’s system also stands out for provisions allowing investors to allocate up to 80 per cent of their contributions to foreign investments. About 40 per cent of that is invested in the US, Mr Ceresino says.Nuveen sees a glowing prospect in convincing savers about the benefits of active management, says Oscar Isoba, its head of business development for Latin America.“The allocation is done on a regional basis and developed markets like the US are accessed mostly through passive vehicles,” Mr Isoba says. “If US active managers gain ground on the performance front, there could be an opportunity to raise assets.”The next large competitor in the market, however, may be the government.President Michelle Bachelet has vowed to create a government-run retirement fund to compete with private sector providers. Her proposal is expected to be presented to the National Congress this year.MetLife’s Mr Schmidt says he takes comfort in the fact that Ms Bachelet presided over an ambitious, and ultimately positive, pension reform initiative in 2008, during her previous term as president.“Overall, it was a great reform, and we think she is going to continue supporting the system,” Mr Schmidt says.Both Mr Schmidt and Principal’s Mr Walker say the system suffers from insufficient savings rather than a lack of competition. They point to potential solutions including higher contributions and greater support for an employer-sponsored option under the voluntary scheme.“We are not against the idea of the government-run AFP because we believe in competition, and if it is fair, we will compete,” Mr Schmidt says.“But we do not think it solves the current problems.”

Titular: MetLife to quit market with sale to Rothesay
Texto: Another UK corporate pensions insurer is to quit the market after MetLife agreed to sell its bulk annuity business to Goldman Sachs-backed Rothesay Life.The US insurer has disposed of the division, which manages £3bn in assets for about 20,000 pensioners at schemes including The Law Society and Vivendi, after warning it did not meet its “financial objectives”.The sale by MetLife, which entered the market in 2007, comes after peer Lucida was sold to Legal & General last year.David Ellis, UK bulk pensions insurance leader at the consultants Mercer, said a dwindling number of competing insurers could put upward pressure on prices.Neither Rothesay nor MetLife would disclose the deal value. Previous transactions have been valued at about 10 per cent of assets under management.The deal is Rothesay’s first since Goldman sold a majority stake to investors including Blackstone and brings its total AUM to about £10bn.Addy Loudiadis, chief executive of Rothesay, said demand for bulk annuities – under which schemes transfer financial responsibilities to insurers for a fee – remained buoyant with transaction levels near record levels.

Titular: Akzo Nobel: beyond the DIY
Subtitular: Büchner is doing a good job but the refurb has far to go
Texto: Ton Büchner, boss of paint and chemicals maker Akzo Nobel, is undertaking some DIY. In the best traditions of home decoration, Mr Büchner is giving the place a good clean and a fresh coat of paint. Costs have been cut (ahead of schedule and above target), working capital is being hammered down, unwanted divisions have been sold, net debt has been cut and everything is looking more shipshape. He has even taken risk out of the pension scheme via a $170m deal with MetLife (although a chunky deficit remains). To top it off, Akzo beat fourth quarter estimates, pushing the shares up 7 per cent on Thursday.But although Akzo Nobel is a more efficient and healthy-looking version of its former self, it is still Akzo Nobel. Mature European markets account for 38 per cent of sales, so the health of the European economy has a big influence on how bright or gloomy the room looks. Currency fluctuations dented group revenues in 2013 but even before that they barely budged. Volume increases in paints were offset by tougher times in speciality chemicals, where prices fell in the fourth quarter. Even if a recovery is on the way, it will not be smooth. A shift to emerging markets is the standard response to such difficulties. Akzo Nobel is moving in that direction but developing nations accounted for 44 per cent of revenues in 2013, no more than in 2012.So while awaiting the European recovery and emerging-markets shift, investors will have to make do with watching Mr Büchner’s DIY. There is certainly more to do. He is aiming for a 14 per cent return on invested capital by 2015, so 2013’s 9.6 per cent leaves room for improvement. A rolling cost-cutting plan, which aims to save €150m-€200m per year to offset inflation, will also be important. That is all fine for the time being but at some point the investment case for Akzo Nobel will have to stretch beyond DIY.Email the Lex team in confidence at lex@ft.com

Titular: AIG / AerCap: come fly with me
Subtitular: Last major sale of non-core assets would not be a clean break for the bailed-out giant
Texto: And then there were none. American International Group on Monday agreed to sell International Lease Finance Corp, its aircraft leasing business, to smaller rival AerCap. It is the last major sale of non-core assets as part of AIG’s post-crisis restructuring. In the five years since its $182bn bailout, AIG has shed assets to repay the US government. AIA, the Asian life assurer, was floated, and the non-US life assurance unit Alico was sold to MetLife. A year ago, the US had recovered the rescue funds plus about $23bn, and the Treasury had sold its entire stake in AIG.But the sale of ILFC is not a clean break and this is where the deal leaves something to be desired. AIG will receive $3bn in cash, plus about 98m shares in Dutch-headquartered AerCap for ILFC. Based on Friday’s closing price, the AerCap shares were worth $2.4bn. That leaves AIG with a 46 per cent stake in ILFC’s new owner, which it can only sell down in stages over a period of nine to 15 months after the deal closes. AIG also is providing AerCap with a $1bn five-year revolving credit facility.At $5.4bn, the purchase price represents a discount to ILFC’s book value – about 0.7 times shareholders’ equity. The upshot is that AIG can hope to make up some of that discount through its new stake in AerCap. AerCap’s shares jumped 33 per cent on Monday, adding about $800m to the value of the deal. The tie-up will result in cost and tax savings – the assets will be moved to Ireland – of about $300m a year.The AerCap deal is worth slightly more to AIG than a previous one with Jumbo Acquisition Limited, a Chinese consortium, for up to 90 per cent of ILFC, which valued the aircraft leasing company at $5.3bn. That transaction, agreed a year ago, was never finalised. This one, although it fails to sever all of AIG’s ties to the aircraft leasing business, has a better chance of getting off the ground.Email the Lex team in confidence at lex@ft.comThis article has been amended to show that AerCap’s shares jumped 33 per cent on Monday, not 8 per cent as previously stated.

Titular: Movers & shakers: November 11
Subtitular: Legal & General Investment Management is building up its newly formed US-based indexing team
Texto: ● Legal & General Investment Management is building up its newly formed US-based indexing team. Chad Rakvin has been appointed as head of US index funds and Shaun Murphy joins as a director in December. Both are moving from Northern Trust Global Investments.● BlueBay, the specialist fixed income and alternative investments manager, has appointed Luc Leclercq as chief operating officer. Mr Leclercq is moving from State Street.● Arti Sharma has joined as head of Northern Trust, Canada, with responsibility for all of the financial services provider’s operations in the Canadian market. Ms Sharma joins from Mercer, where she was custody practice leader.● Pictet Asset Management has appointed Roger Price-Haworth as head of institutional business development for the UK and Ireland. Mr Price-Haworth is moving from BNP Paribas Investment Partners. Anahita Firouzbakht has also moved to Pictet as consultant relations manager from Partners Group.● There are three hires for First State Investments European direct infrastructure team. Volker Häussermann joins as a director from Deutsche Asset & Wealth Management Infrastructure Europe. Batiste Ogier from KPMG and Mats Hope from UBS have moved to the team as senior executive and executive respectively.● Robert Vandersluis, director of global pension investments at GlaxoSmithKline, has joined the board of the London Pensions Fund Authority as a non-executive director.● Nitin Sharma has moved to OVS, a London-based event-driven hedge fund, as an analyst from Ivaldi Capital.● Axiom Alternative Investments has hired Christina Perri as the head of its new international business development department from Winton Capital Management.● David Ryland, a commercial property specialist, has moved to Paul Hastings, the law group, from SJ Berwin.● Tom Ormrod is moving to Legg Mason as business development director for the south of England from F&C where he acted as a sales director since 2010.● Sovereign Capital, the private equity group, has appointed Jeremy Morgan as a director. Mr Morgan joins from Barclays Ventures.● Nick Pemberton has moved from Aviva to MetLife, the insurance group, as strategic accounts manager in its employee benefits business.● Oddo Asset Mangement has recruited Carsten Nerge as Germany and Austria country head from Warburg Invest, where he was head of institutional sales.● Satis, a London-based wealth manager, has appointed David Hearne, previously an independent financial adviser, as wealth management adviser and Matthew Edwards as senior tax manager from a similar tax role at Ernst & Young.

Titular: Prudential Financial drops opposition to stricter oversight
Texto: Prudential Financial, the US insurer, has dropped its opposition to being designated a “systemically important financial institution”, in a blow to other non-bank financial groups that are trying to stave off additional regulation.The company on Friday decided not to mount a legal challenge to a ruling last month by the US Financial Stability Oversight Council that could lead to the imposition of extra capital and liquidity requirements.Other large insurers and fund managers had been watching Prudential’s decision, hoping that a legal challenge would circumscribe FSOC’s power and reduce the likelihood of other companies being designated as Sifis.Prudential “will continue to work with . . . regulators to develop regulatory standards that take into account the differences between insurance companies and banks, particularly in the use of capital, and that benefit consumers and preserve competition within the insurance industry,” it said.Prudential’s decision was being watched by fellow life insurer MetLife, which is also being assessed for a possible Sifi designation. That company also believes it does not deserve the Sifi label and plans to challenge the effort, at least through the FSOC process.Behind MetLife, the asset management industry is being examined by FSOC over whether the failure of the largest fund managers, such as BlackRock and Pimco, might pose a threat to the financial system.Analysts have been reluctant to quantify the potential hit to Prudential’s return on equity from having to set aside additional capital, until the Fed’s rules are clearer, and Prudential had been angry that the process of identifying systemic importance came before there was clarity on the regulatory requirements that come with such a designation.Jay Gelb, a Barclays analyst, predicted the Fed may hold off setting new capital rules for non-bank Sifis until apparent contradictions in the Dodd-Frank reform act are ironed out, perhaps requiring action by Congress. The wording of the law both requires the Fed to take into account differences between banks and other Sifis, and to impose the same capital and liquidity rules.The uncertainty remains a problem for shareholders, however, Mr Gelb said, because Prudential and the other Sifi insurers would be unable to extend share buybacks until capital rules became clear. “[They] may not be subject to stress testing until 2015 . . . Although investors should keep their expectations low for share buybacks (particularly for MetLife and Prudential), it would give these insurers an extra year to organically increase capital levels and prepare for increased oversight.”When FSOC made its designation in September, the two insurance experts on the council and the acting director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, Edward DeMarco, disagreed with the body’s move on Prudential.John Huff, director of the Missouri insurance department and the state insurance expert on the FSOC, said in his dissent that “there appears to be a lack of recognition given to the nature of the insurance business and the authorities and tools available to insurance regulators.” He added that applying banking standards renders “the rationale for designation flawed, insufficient, and unsupportable.”Roy Woodall, the independent member on the council with insurance expertise, said the FSOC’s assessment was not supported by facts or experience. “The underlying analysis utilises scenarios that are antithetical to a fundamental and seasoned understanding of the business of insurance, the insurance regulatory environment, and the state insurance company resolution and guaranty fund systems,” he said.

Titular: Large insurers reserve judgment over global capital standards
Texto: About 50 of the world’s biggest insurance companies are facing fresh uncertainty after regulators unveiled plans for the first industry-wide capital standards.On Wednesday, three months after global regulators designated nine insurers – including Allianz, Prudential and Metlife – as “systemically important”, they put forward separate proposals that would affect an additional 40 companies.The new capital standards are due to take effect from 2019 and apply to insurers that members of the International Association of Insurance Supervisors deem “internationally active”.Narrower criteria are to be applied than those the regulators used to determine the nine too-big-to-fail insurers.They will look mainly at size per se, irrespective of the type of business the insurers do and their interconnectedness with the wider financial system.The standards will apply to insurance companies that have total assets of at least $50bn or write premiums worth at least $10bn a year, and do at least a 10th of their business outside their domestic market or write premiums in at least three jurisdictions.Regulators will have some discretion in determining the final list.Officials say the shake-up is necessary because insurance sector regulations have failed to keep pace with the changing nature of the industry.“It is undeniable that the business of insurance is global,” said Peter Braumüller, who chairs the IAIS’s executive committee. “Global issues demand global responses.”Officials argue that the financial crisis underscored the importance of common global standards – not only in banking.In addition to capital standards, the 50 or so insurers face “qualitative” requirements, including risk management standards and governance procedures.It is undeniable that the business of insurance is global. Global issues demand global responsesIndustry insiders stressed that details remained sketchy and said they would reserve judgment on the plans.Important questions remained about how the global standards would work alongside Solvency II, the EU’s regulatory shake-up.Several other jurisdictions outside the EU – but notably not the US – are planning to implement regimes that are equivalent to Solvency II.Regulators plan to unveil the global standards by the end of 2016 and implement them in full after two years of “testing and refinement”.The proposals would bring insurance regulations more in line with the set-up in banking. Regulators are phasing in the Basel III rulebook over several years.John Fitzpatrick, secretary-general of the global insurance trade body the Geneva Association, said in a statement that the industry was “committed to working with standard setters” on the plan.However, he added: “It is clear that there will be significant challenges to the creation of a global capital standard for insurers, particularly within the timeframe proposed.”The IAIS, which represents insurance regulators in 140 countries, unveiled the plans ahead of its annual meeting in Taipei next week.

Titular: Insurers fall but US indices steady
Subtitular: Insurers fall but US indices steady
Texto: US stock stepped back from record levels following Wednesday’s sharp uptick that was spurred by the Federal Reserve’s announcement that it would not begin to scale back its quantitative easing programme.Insurers were among the worst performers as investors anticipate that the Fed’s efforts to maintain low interest rates will cut into profits.MetLife shares declined 3.2 per cent to $47.08 and are now off 6.8 per cent since the Fed’s announcement.The insurer, known for using Peanuts character Snoopy as its mascot, is up 43 per cent in 2013 as strong earnings and rising interest rates have cheered investors.Expectations that the Fed’s announcement would mark the start of the end of quantitative easing and cause an increase in rates fuelled the rally by insurers, and caused a reversal when tapering was delayed and rates fell, said Suneet Kamath, research analyst at UBS.“I think it’s a situation where sentiment lifted these stocks on expectations for higher interest rates and as that expectation is adjusted downwards, the valuation multiples adjust downwards,” he said.“It’s a move in the right direction, but I’m not sure it’s going to dramatically change the earnings outlook for next year.”Although not back near pre-crisis levels that briefly broke the $70 level, shares of MetLife have steadily recovered despite facing tighter regulation.MetLife was not alone as Lincoln National fell 3.7 per cent to $41.21 and Prudential Financial declined 1.9 per cent to $78.69.The S&P 500 fell 0.2 per cent to 1,722.33, led by a 0.1 per cent rise by the information technology and industrials sectors. The benchmark index touched a new intraday high of 1,729.86 in early trading.The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 0.3 per cent to 15,636.55 and the Nasdaq Composite ticked up 0.2 per cent to 3,789.38.Apple helped keep the Nasdaq in positive territory, rising 1.6 per cent to $472.30. Analysts’ predictions for sales of the new iPhones released this weekend have cheered investors initially disappointed by the company’s new offerings.But Apple shares remain 6.7 per cent lower since the new products were announced.Retailer Rite Aid was among the strongest stocks on the day, up 23.5 per cent to $4.58.The company announced an unexpected profit in the second quarter and lifted its outlook for 2014.Earnings news from ConAgra Foods was not as encouraging as the company missed first-quarter earnings per share expectations.The company warned earlier in September that profits would come in below expectations, sending its shares lower.But the early warning was unable to save ConAgra shares from falling 4 per cent on Thursday to $30.80, now down 11.8 per cent on the past month.Online coupon issuer Groupon benefited from a Stifel Nicolaus upgrade to “buy” from “hold”. Shares in the company added 9.1 per cent to $12.60.Home furnishings retailer Pier 1 Imports also fell after earnings missed analysts’ forecasts. The company also scaled back its 2014 forecast.
